description: The Microsoft Exchange 2016 Exam 70-345 show will help the experienced Exchange Admin who is already familiar with Microsoft Exchange but need to plan, deploy, manage and troubleshoot different components of Microsoft Exchange 2016.  You’ll see powershell and Exchange Admin Center commands that will help to maintain and manage Mailbox Databases, Client Access Services, Transport services, Coexistence and Migration scenarios.  Exchange Expert Brian Svidergol takes each topic in detail and focuses in on the skills measured to give clear understanding of each domain objective called out Microsoft for Exam 70-345

subtitle: Designing and Deploying Microsoft Exchange Server 2016

episodes.description: The Microsoft Exchange 2016 Exam 70-345 show will help the experienced Exchange Admin who is already familiar with Microsoft Exchange but need to plan, deploy, manage and troubleshoot different components of Microsoft Exchange 2016. You’ll see powershell and Exchange Admin Center commands that will help to maintain and manage Mailbox Databases, Client Access Services, Transport services, Coexistence and Migration scenarios. Exchange Expert Brian Svidergol takes each topic in detail and focuses in on the skills measured to give clear understanding of each domain objective called out Microsoft for Exam 70-345
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.893
[SOUND] Hello,
we're about to begin a show on

2
00:00:04.893 --> 00:00:10.954
Microsoft Exchange 2016 for Exam 70-345.

3
00:00:10.954 --> 00:00:13.870
You want to make sure that you're
actually ready to take the exam, so

4
00:00:13.870 --> 00:00:16.520
we're actually have an entire
show based on that.

5
00:00:16.520 --> 00:00:19.130
Before we get started let's talk
a little bit about getting ready for

6
00:00:19.130 --> 00:00:20.590
that exam as well.

7
00:00:20.590 --> 00:00:24.690
Once you're fully prepared, make sure that
you go to your Pearson Vue testing center,

8
00:00:24.690 --> 00:00:27.550
and get registered,
you can do that online as well.

9
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:29.230
But wherever you are in the world,

10
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:31.520
make sure you also know that
you're gonna have to pay a fee for

11
00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:36.290
the exam as well, currently, right now
in the United States, it's about $165.

12
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.480
Make sure you check your local rates, and

13
00:00:38.480 --> 00:00:41.030
you actually find out what
the price is going to be.

14
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:43.990
Once you're registered, you'll go
there on the day of the exam, sit for

15
00:00:43.990 --> 00:00:47.790
the exam and then, of course hopefully,
pass the exam as well.

16
00:00:47.790 --> 00:00:52.070
But to ensure that you are ready and
prepared for that, in our show we're gonna

17
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:55.760
have Mr. Brian as being our subject
matter expert to help us out.

18
00:00:55.760 --> 00:00:58.570
So Brian, what are we gonna
be covering during our show?

19
00:00:59.720 --> 00:01:05.500
>> Thanks Ronnie, so we've actually got,
this exam has six primary topics, and

20
00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:10.550
each of the six topics represents
about 15 or 20% of the exam.

21
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:14.830
So, the bad news is,
you can't focus on one topic because

22
00:01:14.830 --> 00:01:17.600
they're all evenly spread throughout,
you're gonna need to know a little bit

23
00:01:17.600 --> 00:01:19.532
about all these things to get ready for
the exam.

24
00:01:19.532 --> 00:01:23.100
While we walk you through some of
the topics, we're gonna start at the top,

25
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:29.310
the first one is plan deploy, manage,
and troubleshoot mailbox databases.

26
00:01:29.310 --> 00:01:32.060
So this is all about the database side,

27
00:01:32.060 --> 00:01:35.660
it starts off with a lot
of sizing components.

28
00:01:35.660 --> 00:01:38.590
How many databases do you need,
how much storage do you need?

29
00:01:38.590 --> 00:01:44.050
So one of things you want to focus on,
is how to size an environment if you're

30
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:47.486
given a certain set of circumstances, like
maybe you have a couple of thousand users,

31
00:01:47.486 --> 00:01:51.290
they each have a two gig mailbox,
they send 100 messages a day.

32
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:54.370
The tool that you want to take a look at,
make sure you're familiar with,

33
00:01:54.370 --> 00:01:57.130
is Exchange Server sizing calculator.

34
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:00.850
That's that spreadsheet that will help
you calculate out the environment,

35
00:02:00.850 --> 00:02:01.510
the storage,

36
00:02:01.510 --> 00:02:05.750
even the bandwidth if you decide to
go with database availability groups.

37
00:02:05.750 --> 00:02:10.450
So on the database side, there's a ton
of topics, you're also gonna dive into

38
00:02:10.450 --> 00:02:14.970
creating databases, managing databases,
mounting and dismounting,

39
00:02:14.970 --> 00:02:19.900
maybe get into a little bit of that
stuff too, so that's topic number one.

40
00:02:19.900 --> 00:02:26.090
For topic number two plan, deploy, manage,
and troubleshoot Client Access services.

41
00:02:26.090 --> 00:02:32.510
So, what we're talking about here is
the client population like your end users,

42
00:02:32.510 --> 00:02:35.970
and how they get to all the services
that exchange has to offer.

43
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:39.750
So, we're talking about everything
from Outlook connectivity,

44
00:02:39.750 --> 00:02:43.960
to Outlook on the web, to mobile devices,

45
00:02:43.960 --> 00:02:47.910
anyway that anybody can get in and
consume the Exchange Services.

46
00:02:47.910 --> 00:02:50.460
There's a whole bunch of
topics to cover down here,

47
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:53.760
I wanna point out a couple of them.

48
00:02:53.760 --> 00:02:59.200
We have a little bit on authentication,
knowing about form-based authentication,

49
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:05.130
kerberos based authentication, how to set
that stuff, we get into client namespaces,

50
00:03:05.130 --> 00:03:07.990
all the names that people use,
and have to remember.

51
00:03:07.990 --> 00:03:13.460
You think about mail.yourdomain.com, can
you use that across the whole environment,

52
00:03:13.460 --> 00:03:18.360
where do you set that stuff up, and
does it need to be different internally,

53
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:19.450
externally?

54
00:03:19.450 --> 00:03:20.013
All right,

55
00:03:20.013 --> 00:03:24.130
a lot of planning considerations
around the Client Access pieces.

56
00:03:24.130 --> 00:03:28.900
And then also in there, we talk about
some of the networking pieces, too,

57
00:03:28.900 --> 00:03:31.510
like load balancing, and

58
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:37.170
even some site resiliency when it comes
to getting the clients connected.

59
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:40.778
So that's high level topic number two.

60
00:03:40.778 --> 00:03:45.125
The third one is the exchange,
infrastructure, recipients and

61
00:03:45.125 --> 00:03:49.330
security, planning,
deploying, and managing.

62
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:52.825
What you'll find in there is a lot
of stuff on Active Directory,

63
00:03:52.825 --> 00:03:55.960
preparing Active Directory
to have exchange.

64
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:59.740
We're talking about schema updates,
domain preparation, and

65
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:07.115
the other pieces are around security,
mail unable to object permissions.

66
00:04:07.115 --> 00:04:09.800
These is a very tough area,

67
00:04:09.800 --> 00:04:13.650
all the permission stuff, we have
a lot of role based access control, so

68
00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:17.580
a couple of things I wanna point out here,
how do we give our administrators

69
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:21.480
access to the environment,
without giving them more than they need?

70
00:04:21.480 --> 00:04:24.110
So it's all about the principle
of least privilege right?

71
00:04:24.110 --> 00:04:26.270
Your gonna need to know
the built in roles,

72
00:04:26.270 --> 00:04:28.850
your gonna need to know
how to customize them.

73
00:04:28.850 --> 00:04:34.060
On the permission side, we're gonna dive
into anything from mailbox permissions,

74
00:04:34.060 --> 00:04:36.220
to public folder permission.

75
00:04:36.220 --> 00:04:39.590
How do you give other people
access to somebody's mailbox?

76
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:41.410
Think about shared mailboxes, and

77
00:04:41.410 --> 00:04:44.410
what if you just wanted to
give them access to a folder?

78
00:04:44.410 --> 00:04:46.689
You've got a lot of granularity there, and

79
00:04:46.689 --> 00:04:49.902
these are the details you're
gonna need to know for the exam.

80
00:04:49.902 --> 00:04:52.110
All right,
let's talk about the next topic.

81
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:59.270
Plan, deploy, manage compliance,
archiving, eDiscovery, and auditing.

82
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:00.950
So this is an interesting one,

83
00:05:00.950 --> 00:05:06.600
very closely related to security,
there is a turnout detail here.

84
00:05:06.600 --> 00:05:10.150
When we talk about compliance and
archiving,

85
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:14.907
what we are talking about is, do we need
to maintain data at the organisation, and

86
00:05:14.907 --> 00:05:18.720
if so how long, and
if we do, how do we do that?

87
00:05:18.720 --> 00:05:22.800
We can go with archiving as one example,
when we thing of archiving,

88
00:05:22.800 --> 00:05:26.920
that's taking your mail data,
and keeping it for the long term.

89
00:05:26.920 --> 00:05:30.350
There's a lot of choices and planning
considerations, for example, do you wanna

90
00:05:30.350 --> 00:05:34.130
keep that archiving data on premises,
or do you wanna move it up to the Cloud,

91
00:05:34.130 --> 00:05:36.280
what are the different things
you need to think about there?

92
00:05:36.280 --> 00:05:42.630
When we talk about eDiscovery, we're
talking about the ability for the security

93
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:46.890
team to take a look at all of the mail
data throughout the whole environment,

94
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:50.640
looking for something maybe to do with
a legal case or something similar.

95
00:05:50.640 --> 00:05:54.435
For the exam, you're gonna need to know
how to set up eDiscovery, how to run

96
00:05:54.435 --> 00:05:58.730
eDiscovery, and what permissions at
you're gonna need in order to do that.

97
00:05:58.730 --> 00:06:03.170
And then finally, auditing for
this particular topic.

98
00:06:03.170 --> 00:06:07.270
Auditing is capturing all of
the actions that were performed

99
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:10.580
typically by an administrator
while they're doing their job.

100
00:06:10.580 --> 00:06:13.833
Which commandlets did they run,
which parameters, who ran it,

101
00:06:13.833 --> 00:06:15.940
what did they run, what did they change?

102
00:06:15.940 --> 00:06:17.920
You're gonna need that stuff
when you wanna go back and

103
00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:23.185
figure out what caused maybe an outage or
some kind of bad configuration change.

104
00:06:23.185 --> 00:06:25.435
In addition to
the administrative side though,

105
00:06:25.435 --> 00:06:29.095
you can also do auditing on
the mailboxes themselves.

106
00:06:29.095 --> 00:06:31.435
So if you're ever in a trouble shooting
situation and you wanna figure out,

107
00:06:31.435 --> 00:06:35.745
what's going on with the user's mailbox,
you can turn on auditing on the mailbox

108
00:06:35.745 --> 00:06:39.895
for specific actions, whether they're
creates, or deletes, or removes, and

109
00:06:39.895 --> 00:06:42.685
in troubleshooting scenarios,
you can dig that data up.

110
00:06:42.685 --> 00:06:45.810
So you're definitely gonna
need to know about that.

111
00:06:45.810 --> 00:06:50.180
And then our final topic is implement and
manage coexistence,

112
00:06:50.180 --> 00:06:54.460
hybrid scenarios,
migration, and federation.

113
00:06:54.460 --> 00:06:59.000
This is a whole flurry of topics,
and their big ones too.

114
00:06:59.000 --> 00:07:04.000
This is where we'll get into
a little bit of Office 365,

115
00:07:04.000 --> 00:07:06.810
when you think about taking your
on premises environment, and

116
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:11.020
configuring it to be a hybrid
environment with Office 365.

117
00:07:11.020 --> 00:07:15.110
Maybe you're gonna have some mailboxes
on-premises, maybe you're gonna have some

118
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:18.471
in the Cloud, maybe you're gonna
move everything into the Cloud, but

119
00:07:18.471 --> 00:07:20.712
you're gonna need that
co-existence time for

120
00:07:20.712 --> 00:07:22.866
a little while where you
have to manage both.

121
00:07:22.866 --> 00:07:26.560
You're gonna need to know the details
around that set-up process,

122
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:29.553
what are the requirement,
how do users authenticate,

123
00:07:29.553 --> 00:07:32.620
do we need to do any sinking
up to Azure Active Directory?

124
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:39.630
Beyond that we get into migration and
coexistence from earlier version,

125
00:07:39.630 --> 00:07:45.609
so think about Exchange 2010 or 2013, you
wanna bring 2016 into your environment,

126
00:07:46.620 --> 00:07:51.350
how do you do that, what are you gonna
need to know, what do you do once it's in?

127
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:54.140
And then how do you get
rid of the old stuff, so

128
00:07:54.140 --> 00:07:55.570
there's a bunch of topics around that.

129
00:07:55.570 --> 00:07:59.580
Everything from moving mailboxes
whether individually or

130
00:07:59.580 --> 00:08:02.340
in batches, moving the public folders.

131
00:08:02.340 --> 00:08:06.000
And then the last little piece you
need to move before you can start

132
00:08:06.000 --> 00:08:09.080
the decommissioning process, and
there's a lot of details even

133
00:08:09.080 --> 00:08:13.510
around the decommissioning process, and
I think that are covered here on the exam.

134
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:19.130
So, that's quite a bit of stuff here,
I do have one more that I left off,

135
00:08:19.130 --> 00:08:24.740
and that's the plan, deploy, manage and
troubleshoot transport services.

136
00:08:24.740 --> 00:08:28.540
So, transport services
are the backend services that

137
00:08:28.540 --> 00:08:33.850
handle the flow of email data, when you
send an email from one person to another,

138
00:08:33.850 --> 00:08:38.330
whether it's inside the company,
or maybe out to the internet.

139
00:08:38.330 --> 00:08:42.710
There's a whole transport pipeline
architecture, some of which is new to

140
00:08:42.710 --> 00:08:46.250
Exchange 2016, that you're gonna
need to know the details about.

141
00:08:46.250 --> 00:08:49.660
You wanna really know, how does
an email get from one place to another,

142
00:08:49.660 --> 00:08:53.730
how does it choose which route to go down,
what are the infrastructure

143
00:08:53.730 --> 00:08:58.750
considerations to change that routing,
maybe enhance a little bit?

144
00:08:58.750 --> 00:09:00.820
We're gonna dive into
those details in the show,

145
00:09:00.820 --> 00:09:03.390
so that you're comfortable as you
get those topics on your exam.

146
00:09:04.870 --> 00:09:09.760
So, that is a breakdown of high level of
everything we want to cover on this show.

147
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:14.900
We're gonna dive into when we talk
across the topic a lot of PowerShell.

148
00:09:14.900 --> 00:09:19.470
So, most everything today, from an
administrative prospective, you can do it

149
00:09:19.470 --> 00:09:24.260
from the GUI components, like Exchange
admin center or from PowerShell.

150
00:09:24.260 --> 00:09:27.960
For exam preparation,
I like to focus on the PowerShell pieces,

151
00:09:27.960 --> 00:09:30.350
because those are the most testable.

152
00:09:30.350 --> 00:09:33.680
So, you'll see, we're gonna cover
a lot of the command line, but

153
00:09:33.680 --> 00:09:36.500
when it's appropriate,
we're also gonna go into the Gooey,

154
00:09:36.500 --> 00:09:40.510
because sometimes it shows you
a good end user experience and

155
00:09:40.510 --> 00:09:43.560
what the impacts and
effects of some of these changes are.

156
00:09:43.560 --> 00:09:47.580
So, be prepared for a lot of PowerShell,
and let's get ready.

157
00:09:48.610 --> 00:09:53.790
If you think that you're gonna be
taking the exam 70-345, then we have

158
00:09:53.790 --> 00:09:58.596
all this information coming
up in the show, stay tuned.

159
00:09:58.596 --> 00:10:01.459
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss and examine the concepts of planning for Mailbox Database in Exchange 2016.  They discuss the use of the planning calculator, storage capacity and storage architecture considerations.  Also covered are planning uses such as auto reseed and basic virtualization requirements too.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at creating and managing task for validating and creating the mailbox databases. Brian shows how to setup the JetStress, create and configure the mailbox database using powershell and manage the created mailbox database using the GUI.  The last topic he emphasizes is the configuring the transaction log and how to move them.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Mailbox DBs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with planning, deploying and managing the high-availability solutions for mailbox databases.  They identify failure domains, discuss solutions that meet SLA requirements, plan out software updates and maintenance. Brian also describes a change management.  Brian also demonstrates how to setup a DAG and add elements to make it work!
episodes.title: HA Solutions for Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss the need for setting up a File Share Witness (FSW).  The discuss the need and take a look at configuring it in Azure as well ask discuss hosting a DAG in the cloud.
episodes.title: HA Solutions for Mailbox DBs Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie dive into the concepts of site-resilient DAGs.  Brian describes the considerations of placing the FSW for a given scenario.  They discuss the idea of cross-site DAGs.  He shows how to configure for the DAC—Dataceter Activation Coordination and they mention the used of an alternate fileshare witness.
episodes.title: Site-Resilient Database Availability Group

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Brian begin guiding viewers through the aspects troubleshooting mailbox DBs.  They run commands to help to test the replication health and look at performance issues. Also They demonstration how to troubleshoot the DB copy activation and failures.  Brian describes issues surrounding quorum issues that may arise and help us to understand the concept of data center activation.
episodes.title: Monitor and Troubleshoot Mailbox DBs

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian examine the of the backup and recovery solutions for the mailbox databases.  The mention RTO and RPO requirements, lagged mailboxes, failures, public folders and the dial tone restore!
episodes.title: Backup and Recover Mailbox DBs

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot mailbox databases

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian discuss Client Access Services requirements and considerations.  They discuss name space considerations for CAS.  Brian then describes the differences between proxying and redirection.  He shows how to deploy the certificates to the exchange components and some additional service setups.
episodes.title: Client Access Services

episodes.description: {Description}In this episode, Brian and Ronnie introduce us to the authentication components, as well as the Offline Address Book, the Hierarchical Address List and Address Book Policies.  The emphasize how to configure and when to use those services.  Each of these services, according to Brian help end user experience.
episodes.title: Client Access Services Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian discuss the topics of mobility and loadbalancing.  Brian introduces a guest expert, Elias Mereb to help configure OWA for devices, to demonstrate how to configure Allow Block Quarantine and configuring for Office Apps.  Brian and Ronnie also discuss briefly the issues configuring namespace load balancing and affinity.  As well as cover the topics of layer 4 and layer 7 load balancing methods.
episodes.title: Mobility and Load Balancing

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Brian take a look into troubleshooting some of the common items in Exchange such as Outlook Anywhere, Outlook MAPI over HTTP, Exchange Web Services and Outlook on the Web.  They demonstrate the commands and utilities that will help you get the bottom of your connectivity issues with Exchange 2016
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Client Connectivity

episodes.description: In the episode, Ronnie and Brian continue with troubleshooting pop and map, authentication, autodiscover, ActiveSync and redirection and proxy.  Brian discusses and demonstrates the tools available in each case of when and where to use them for the best results in troubleshooting Exchange 2016 connectivity issues.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot Client Connectivity Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at some familiar topics from site-resiliency perspective.  They review namespaces and describe the different models involved.  They discuss the basics of site failover and switchover by distinguishing them and reminding us of the importance of the witness server, they review the reduced requirements of certificate and expected client behaviors during failover and switchover
episodes.title: Site Resilient Client Access Services

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot client access services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with planning transport services.  The discuss the implications of making sure that the Transport Service meets the SLA requirements listed.  Along with this, they plan for both inter-site mail flow and inter-org mail flow and redundant intra-site scenarios.  Another consideration is also planning the use of SafetyNet and Shadow Redundancy.  Lastly they take look at planning for multiple services that must be considered for the transport services to be ready to go.
episodes.title: Plan Deploy and Manage Transport
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:06.493 --> 00:00:08.234
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.234 --> 00:00:12.068
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.068 --> 00:00:15.512
>> Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.512 --> 00:00:17.450
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:17.450 --> 00:00:20.811
And today you're watching planning,
deploying, and

8
00:00:20.811 --> 00:00:24.684
managing Transport Services
in Microsoft Exchange 2016.

9
00:00:24.684 --> 00:00:28.553
And here with us, once again, is our
Exchange expert, Mr. Brian Swidergal.

10
00:00:28.553 --> 00:00:31.110
Brian, welcome back to our studios,
I'm glad you're here with us.

11
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:34.420
Okay, now Brian, as we get started and

12
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:39.260
we start to take a look at our first topic
here on the Transport Services, right?

13

00:11:56.540 --> 00:11:59.610

00:11:59.610 --> 00:12:04.160

00:12:07.970 --> 00:12:13.390

00:12:13.390 --> 00:12:16.680

00:12:16.680 --> 00:12:22.390
Safety nets responsible to hold a copy of

00:12:22.390 --> 00:12:26.770
After that period of time elapses,

00:12:26.770 --> 00:12:30.140

right, it works in

00:16:48.990 --> 00:16:55.900
The primary difference with it is that it

282
00:16:55.900 --> 00:16:58.700
And I think some of you guys are probably
trying to visualize, well, wait,

283
00:16:58.700 --> 00:17:00.760
how does it protect them
before they are sent?

284
00:17:00.760 --> 00:17:01.660
Let's show that in a diagram.

285
00:17:03.702 --> 00:17:08.200
So similarly, out here, we've got
two sites, Site1 and Site2 up here.

286
00:17:08.200 --> 00:17:09.850
We've got our DAG.

287
00:17:09.850 --> 00:17:12.380
And the first thing that happens.

288
00:17:12.380 --> 00:17:14.450
We got an SMTP server on the internet.

289
00:17:15.670 --> 00:17:19.370
And it's gonna send an email message
to the primary mailbox server.

290
00:17:19.370 --> 00:17:23.440
We're calling it the primary mailbox
server in shadow redundancy terms.

291
00:17:23.440 --> 00:17:25.450
It's just another mailbox server.

292
00:17:25.450 --> 00:17:27.770
But that's the one that got the message.

293
00:17:27.770 --> 00:17:32.240
Before it initiates
delivery to the database,

294
00:17:33.310 --> 00:17:37.930
it establishes an SFTP
session to a mailbox server

295
00:17:37.930 --> 00:17:42.640
in a second site that's part of the DAG,
and that one we call the shadow server.

296
00:17:43.750 --> 00:17:49.060
The shadow server responds and says, hey,
I got your message, we're good here.

297
00:17:49.060 --> 00:17:53.870
And only at that point the actual
first server says to this server on

298
00:17:53.870 --> 00:17:58.290
the Internet, hey, we're good,
I got your message, transmission complete.

299
00:17:59.900 --> 00:18:04.040
That's, in a nutshell,
how the shadow redundancy works.

300
00:18:04.040 --> 00:18:05.910
So it's before they are sent.

301
00:18:05.910 --> 00:18:09.740
The interesting thing is that
safety net is still working

302
00:18:09.740 --> 00:18:11.080
after the message is sent.

303
00:18:11.080 --> 00:18:13.060
So you've got protection,
kind of, on both sides.

00:19:46.562 --> 00:19:50.670
records, that's the long name of
MX records, are responsible for

329
00:19:50.670 --> 00:19:55.642
enabling mail servers on the internet to
find your email server on the internet and

330
00:19:55.642 --> 00:19:57.900
ultimately deliver you mail to you.

00:19:57.900 --> 00:20:02.094
I have a diagram I want to walk through

332
00:20:07.307 --> 00:20:11.630
Okay, so we've got two sites,
Site 1 and Site 2.

333
00:20:11.630 --> 00:20:16.930
And we've got an MX record

334
00:20:16.930 --> 00:20:23.700
that we're gonna call Mail domain dot com.

335
00:20:23.700 --> 00:20:28.500
Over here we've got another
MX record mail too.

336
00:20:28.500 --> 00:20:33.529
The only difference between
them is that we've got an MX

337
00:20:33.529 --> 00:20:39.190
record preference of 10 on Site 1 and
20 on Site 2.

338
00:20:39.190 --> 00:20:43.380
So what the preference does it says,
whoever has the lowest preference,

339
00:20:43.380 --> 00:20:47.090
in this case it's ten,
that's who gets the mail first.

340
00:20:47.090 --> 00:20:50.570
The higher preference is never actually
used unless there's a problem with

341
00:20:50.570 --> 00:20:51.820
the lower preference.

342
00:20:51.820 --> 00:20:54.390
So in the case of our diagram here

00:20:54.390 --> 00:20:59.320
all the mail in-bound from the internet
is always gonna go to Site 1.

344
00:20:59.320 --> 00:21:04.040
If there's a problem with Site 1,
say, the Edge servers go down,

345
00:21:04.040 --> 00:21:08.490
then we have what some people
refer to as a backup MX record,

346
00:21:08.490 --> 00:21:10.420
which points all the mail to Site 2.

347
00:21:10.420 --> 00:21:13.150
In this particular configuration,

348
00:21:13.150 --> 00:21:16.630
this kind of guarantees that
you don't lose any email.

349
00:21:16.630 --> 00:21:21.410
If you didn't have a backup MX record or
another one pointing somewhere else, well,

350
00:21:21.410 --> 00:21:23.210
when your perimeter network
goes down in Site 1,

351
00:21:23.210 --> 00:21:26.560
you're gonna lose inbound internet email.

352
00:21:26.560 --> 00:21:29.610

messages to you are gonna resend and

00:21:29.610 --> 00:21:33.120

00:28:43.715 --> 00:28:48.764
MX records Brian also reminded us how
important it is to have both that

469
00:28:48.764 --> 00:28:53.726
initial one as well as the secondary
MX record that we need in place,

470
00:28:53.726 --> 00:28:56.960
all that's very important for us too.

471
00:28:56.960 --> 00:29:01.140
And then of course, some of the other
services that you of course can configure.

472
00:29:01.140 --> 00:29:03.520
Brian showed us the one that
most people get tripped on, and

473
00:29:03.520 --> 00:29:06.970
that's the setting up of
the Edge transport to.

474
00:29:06.970 --> 00:29:10.928
Now, if you're going wow,
that was a ton inside of that episode,

475
00:29:10.928 --> 00:29:14.975
there are more episodes to come for
the idea of transport services.

476
00:29:14.975 --> 00:29:18.920
So we are glad that you're staying
with us again for more that's to come.

477
00:29:18.920 --> 00:29:23.650
But for this episode that is plenty, and
that means it is time for us to sign off.

478
00:29:23.650 --> 00:29:26.857
So for ITPro.TV,
I've been you're host Ronnie Wong.

479
00:29:26.857 --> 00:29:28.041
>> And I'm Bryan.

480
00:29:28.041 --> 00:29:32.752
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Exchange 2016 shows.

481
00:29:32.752 --> 00:29:38.664
[MUSIC]

482
00:29:38.664 --> 00:29:42.018
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Brian and Ronnie dive into troubleshooting the exchange 2016 transport services.  They take a look at the exchange logs and emphasize using powershell to help format tranport logs for readabiiity.  Brian also helps to identify issues for using a shared namespace and SMTP mail flow. They take a look at mail flow issues and TLS issues and take a look at new issues dealing with the Transport Architecture.
episodes.title: Troubleshoot and Monitor Transport Services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie examine common topics already covered previously with a focus on the transport services.  They discuss and show the use of the preference values for MX records for failover.  Brian describes the resubmission and rerouting queues that need managing and show their default settings.  Along with these topics, Brian and Ronnie take a look at send/receive connectors for site resiliency and describe consideration for transport failover and switchover.
episodes.title: Message Hygiene

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie examine common topics already covered previously with a focus on the transport services.  They discuss and show the use of the preference values for MX records for failover.  Brian describes the resubmission and rerouting queues that need managing and show their default settings.  Along with these topics, Brian and Ronnie take a look at send/receive connectors for site resiliency and describe consideration for transport failover and switchover.
episodes.title: Site Resilient Transport Services

topics.title: Plan, deploy, manage, and troubleshoot transport services

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at the preparing AD DS for exchange installation.  They describe some of the planning considerations for the number of DCs and GCS.  They also discuss DNS changes that may be required for Exchange.  Brian then demonstrates Extending the Active Directory Schema through powershell as well as preparing all the domains in the forest.  The guys briefly describe site topology considerations.  Brian takes the times to configure a throttling policy to minimize the impact of big volume users of Exchange.
episodes.title: Active Directory DS for Exchange

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie begin with creating and configuring mail-enable_objects.  They demonstrate how to create an existingAD user’s  mailbox as well as how to create the AD user and Mailbox with a single command. They also create resource and room mailboxes for scheduling and configure users and contacts.  Brian configures a distribution list and emphasizes its usage along with linked mailboxes so users can share the same source address and he sets up public folders for the exchange environment.
episodes.title: Mail Enabled Objects

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at mail-enabled object permission.  This is view that affects and is noticed by the end-users of exchange.  They describe the difference between “Send As” and “Send-On_Behalf”.  They also describe the effects of using mailbox folder permissions and mailbox permissions.  Brian shows setting up the room mailbox delegates to work and configuring auto-mapping and lastly, he configures the public folder permissions.
episodes.title: Mail Enabled Object Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a dive into the RBAC used by Exchange 2016.  They discuss the use of built in groups and cmdlets.  They demonstrate how to configure custom-scoped groups and used unscoped roles too.  Brian give a brief overview for an delegated setup for exchange and what is involved.  He also demonstrates some of the most common poweshell commands used in troubleshooting and describes the use of user assignment policies
episodes.title: Role Based Access Control (RBAC)

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at using Bitlocker and S/MIME as part of planning an exchange security strategy.  Brian demonstrates enabling the Bitlocker Encryption and shows how we can verify its configuration.  They discuss some of the performance issues and options that are available during its setup.  Brian also discusses S/MIME to secure messages between users.  Brian demonstrate how it’s enabled and what requirements there are for using it.
episodes.title: Plan a Security Strategy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.285
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.285 --> 00:00:06.371
I'm your host live [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.371 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:12.323
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.323 --> 00:00:15.072
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.072 --> 00:00:17.340
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:17.340 --> 00:00:18.120
And today,

8
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:22.630
you're watching taking a look at planning
an appropriate security strategy.

9
00:00:22.630 --> 00:00:26.850
And here to help us out, is our
Exchange expert Mr. Brian Svidergol.

10
00:00:26.850 --> 00:00:31.180
Brian, where we gonna begin
with Exchange security

11
00:00:31.180 --> 00:00:33.611
strategies here when we
start talking about it?.

12
00:00:33.611 --> 00:00:36.290
>> So Ronnie, we've got two topics today.

13
00:00:36.290 --> 00:00:38.890
First one we're gonna cover is BitLocker.

14
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:43.510
BitLocker is a drive encryption technology
built into the Windows operating system

15
00:00:43.510 --> 00:00:45.750
that you can use to
protect data on the drive.

16
00:00:46.880 --> 00:00:47.530
Here's the deal.

17
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:50.470
It's fully supported under Exchange.

18
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:53.180
You can encrypt
the operating system volume,

19
00:00:53.180 --> 00:00:57.120
your data volumes, any of your volumes
you can encrypt with BitLocker.

20
00:00:57.120 --> 00:00:59.550
Let's cover a couple
basics before we dive in.

21
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:05.320
So, BitLocker relies on some sort
of security mechanism to unlock and

22
00:01:05.320 --> 00:01:06.710
protect the data.

23
00:01:06.710 --> 00:01:10.480
You got two options here, one you
can have a trusted platform module,

24
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:14.110
that's a hardware chip we
normally refer to it as a TPM.

25
00:01:14.110 --> 00:01:18.450
It's typically in any late model computer
that you buy today whether it be a client

26
00:01:18.450 --> 00:01:21.410
computer or
a server you always will have a TPM.

27
00:01:21.410 --> 00:01:26.120
When you do, you unlock some of
the advanced features of BitLocker.

28
00:01:26.120 --> 00:01:30.760
And in our lab environment,
unfortunately we're in a virtual

29
00:01:30.760 --> 00:01:34.760
environment where TPMs
are less likely to be.

30
00:01:34.760 --> 00:01:38.820
But they are starting to show
up in the virtual enviroment,

31
00:01:38.820 --> 00:01:40.320
starting with server 2016.

32
00:01:40.320 --> 00:01:41.790
So for us, we don't have a TPM.

33
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:44.780
That means we don't have some
of the advanced features.

34
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:47.350
So for when you do have a TPM,

35
00:01:47.350 --> 00:01:50.170
let me give you one of these
features that's important.

36
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:53.170
You can do an automatic drive unlock, so

37
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:56.570
on startup BitLocker wants to
check to see if the TPMs there.

38
00:01:56.570 --> 00:02:00.010
If it's there and everything checks out,
the drive automatically unlocks and

39
00:02:00.010 --> 00:02:02.550
you can get access to
all that encrypted data.

40
00:02:02.550 --> 00:02:05.640
Without a TPM,
which is what we have in the lab,

41
00:02:05.640 --> 00:02:09.250
we're gonna be forced to enter
a password to unlock the drive.

42
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:12.160
On an Exchange server,
that's a bit of a degradation, right?

43
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:15.660
You restart the Exchange server,
Exchange wants to come up.

44
00:02:15.660 --> 00:02:16.990
It can't reach your database.

45
00:02:16.990 --> 00:02:18.590
You got it on an encrypted drive.

46
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:22.930
Services fail to start, you're typing in
a password, just not a good situation.

47
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:26.560
However, we're still gonna be able to
demonstrate the core techniques and

48
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:28.330
have it turn it on and stuff like that.

49
00:02:28.330 --> 00:02:30.650
We just won't have the TPM.

50
00:02:30.650 --> 00:02:35.500
So without further ado, let's take a look
at the process and walk through it.

51
00:02:35.500 --> 00:02:38.110
We're on mailbox server number two here.

52
00:02:39.290 --> 00:02:42.470
And our first step is to add a roll.

53
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:48.872
We're going to pick
mailbox server number two.

54
00:02:51.032 --> 00:02:55.170
We're gonna go to actually feature
BitLocker Drive Encryption.

55
00:02:55.170 --> 00:02:58.170
It's gonna add a couple additional items.

56
00:02:58.170 --> 00:03:03.570
We're gonna hit Add Features, click Next,
and then we're gonna click Install.

57
00:03:05.610 --> 00:03:10.000
After this goes through,
we're gonna need to reboot the server and

58
00:03:10.000 --> 00:03:13.120
then we're gonna continue on
with the actual configuration.

59
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:16.180
At this point the role or
feature will be installed, but

60
00:03:16.180 --> 00:03:19.020
we still won't have BitLocker
configured anywhere.

61
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:24.004
>> Now Brian, if we enable this,
let's say that we've got multiple

62
00:03:24.004 --> 00:03:29.082
Exchange servers and multiple databases,
where all this is kept.

63
00:03:29.082 --> 00:03:32.517
As we're configuring this and going
through and everything is coming back up.

64
00:03:32.517 --> 00:03:36.916
Are we gonna experience any performance
degradation on the ones that either have

65
00:03:36.916 --> 00:03:39.160
it or the ones that don't have it?

66
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:41.960
In other words that mixed environment
where we have some with BitLocker and

67
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:43.460
some without.

68
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:45.640
>> Yeah, it's a good question,
while you're asking that,

69
00:03:45.640 --> 00:03:48.140
I'm gonna answer that,
it's prompting for a restart.

70
00:03:48.140 --> 00:03:52.750
So let's go ahead and kick the restart of,
and then I'll get right back to that.

71
00:03:52.750 --> 00:03:56.850
So the role,
well the feature finished installing.

72
00:03:56.850 --> 00:03:58.285
And we are going to restart.

73
00:04:03.521 --> 00:04:05.440
And restart.

74
00:04:05.440 --> 00:04:09.437
So while we are waiting for
the restart and kicking that back off,

75
00:04:09.437 --> 00:04:14.534
I think you're asking about potential
performance degradation with BitLocker.

76
00:04:14.534 --> 00:04:20.805
Microsoft has advised that there is
an up to 11% hit on performance.

77
00:04:20.805 --> 00:04:23.489
Typically though it's in
the single digits, so but

78
00:04:23.489 --> 00:04:25.565
it's something you wanna account for.

79
00:04:25.565 --> 00:04:27.573
And if you remember on day one,

80
00:04:27.573 --> 00:04:32.528
we were talking about sizing your
environment, Iops, disk performance.

81
00:04:32.528 --> 00:04:35.358
If you're going to use BitLocker
across your environment,

82
00:04:35.358 --> 00:04:37.720
it's certainly something
you want to factor in.

83
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:42.700
>> So, Brian as this reboot is happening,
right, and the role is getting installed.

84
00:04:42.700 --> 00:04:46.920
This is where it is actually putting
the BitLocker pieces in place, so

85
00:04:46.920 --> 00:04:50.782
when it reboots we should
have BitLocker ready to go?

86
00:04:50.782 --> 00:04:54.530
>> So BitLocker itself will be
available to use after the reboot.

87
00:04:54.530 --> 00:04:58.200
Then it's up to us to decide do we
want it on the operating system drive,

88
00:04:58.200 --> 00:05:00.200
the Exchange data drive?

89
00:05:00.200 --> 00:05:03.010
We choose and
then we manually configure that.

90
00:05:03.010 --> 00:05:06.390
What we're going to do in our
demonstration is we have a third

91
00:05:06.390 --> 00:05:07.090
data drive.

92
00:05:07.090 --> 00:05:10.160
It's not holding any data and
it's nice and small.

93
00:05:10.160 --> 00:05:12.920
That will allow us to go ahead and
configure BitLocker run through

94
00:05:12.920 --> 00:05:16.150
the process without impacting Exchange for
right now.

95
00:05:16.150 --> 00:05:17.050
>> Sounds pretty good.

96
00:05:17.050 --> 00:05:20.550
Do you think our server
has now finally rebooted?

97
00:05:20.550 --> 00:05:21.680
>> Let's take a look.

98
00:05:21.680 --> 00:05:23.035
It looks like it's coming back up

99
00:05:23.035 --> 00:05:32.488
here.

100
00:05:32.488 --> 00:05:34.830
>> It, yep?

101
00:05:34.830 --> 00:05:37.770
It looks like we probably need to
switch on over to the computer screen

102
00:05:37.770 --> 00:05:39.610
instead of the white board there.

103
00:05:39.610 --> 00:05:40.970
There we go, excellent.

104
00:05:40.970 --> 00:05:42.800
Cool.
>> All right just coming back up you

105
00:05:42.800 --> 00:05:44.300
can see it's working on features.

106
00:05:44.300 --> 00:05:47.716
This is pretty typical if you get
into it right as it comes up.

107
00:05:50.487 --> 00:05:52.970
All right, so now we are back in.

108
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:58.730
BitLocker is installed but
I wanna point out if we look at

109
00:05:58.730 --> 00:06:03.060
our drive configuration there's no
indication that anything's encrypted.

110
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:06.700
I'll show you what it does look
like after it does get encrypted.

111
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:10.170
The X drive is the one
that we want to configure.

112
00:06:10.170 --> 00:06:15.286
And let me make this a little smaller so
we can do a little zooming in.

113
00:06:15.286 --> 00:06:19.149
So we're right-clicking on the X drive.

114
00:06:19.149 --> 00:06:23.372
And there's a little option right here
that says, Turn on BitLocker, and

115
00:06:23.372 --> 00:06:25.730
that's gonna be specific to that drive.

116
00:06:27.980 --> 00:06:28.980
So we will do that.

117
00:06:30.350 --> 00:06:34.950
And we're now prompted with
how we wanna unlock the drive.

118
00:06:34.950 --> 00:06:37.550
And this is, one of the reasons
that we're getting this prompt

119
00:06:37.550 --> 00:06:39.490
is because we don't have a TPM here.

120
00:06:39.490 --> 00:06:41.480
So we're going to use a password.

121
00:06:43.500 --> 00:06:45.648
And let's see if we can come up
with something really strong.

122
00:06:48.818 --> 00:06:50.090
We're going to click Next.

123
00:06:52.190 --> 00:06:57.040
The recovery key, if we forget the
password, is our way back into the drive.

124
00:06:57.040 --> 00:07:00.510
So in this case we need to save it
off; you can optionally print it.

125
00:07:00.510 --> 00:07:01.570
I've never been a big fan of

126
00:07:01.570 --> 00:07:02.480
printing them,
>> Yes,

127
00:07:02.480 --> 00:07:04.400
>> But I do like to save them to a file

128
00:07:04.400 --> 00:07:08.770
and generally I like to save
them somewhere off the server.

129
00:07:08.770 --> 00:07:12.626
So in this case we're on NBX2,
why don't we put this over on NBX1.

130
00:07:12.626 --> 00:07:19.010
Maybe we'll throw it into the temp
directory and then we'll click Next.

131
00:07:19.010 --> 00:07:22.990
And then our next option, how much
of the drive do you want to encrypt?

132
00:07:22.990 --> 00:07:26.740
So you can do Used Space Only.

133
00:07:26.740 --> 00:07:28.870
Or you can encrypt the entire drive.

134
00:07:28.870 --> 00:07:31.210
I always recommend going
with the entire drive.

135
00:07:31.210 --> 00:07:34.970
Because Used Space Only will encrypt
the data that you have on there now.

136
00:07:34.970 --> 00:07:39.420
But if you had data on there previously
that you deleted, well it's not gonna

137
00:07:39.420 --> 00:07:43.470
encrypt that empty space and some of that
old data could still be recoverable.

138
00:07:43.470 --> 00:07:46.040
So we're gonna flip down to
encrypt the entire drive.

139
00:07:46.040 --> 00:07:50.129
You'll note that it does say that it's
a little bit slower but that's okay.

140
00:07:50.129 --> 00:07:53.756
And then we can choose between
the compatible mode, that's for

141
00:07:53.756 --> 00:07:57.194
drive than can be removed from the device,
like a USB drive.

142
00:07:57.194 --> 00:08:01.971
Or the newest encryption mode for us, it's
a fixed disk, so we're gonna go with that.

143
00:08:01.971 --> 00:08:05.424
And now we're ready to start encrypting.

144
00:08:05.424 --> 00:08:09.300
You'll notice that lock icon, let me
zoom in and show it a little closer.

145
00:08:11.610 --> 00:08:15.950
So the X drive, right here,
has this little lock icon on it now

146
00:08:15.950 --> 00:08:18.730
as it's going through,
still kind of grayed out.

147
00:08:18.730 --> 00:08:23.850
But, that lock icon is going
to be the icon to watch for.

148
00:08:23.850 --> 00:08:26.346
It's a quick way to figure out
if a drive's encrypted and

149
00:08:26.346 --> 00:08:27.391
if a drive is unlocked.

150
00:08:33.881 --> 00:08:37.890
>> So, Brian, if we actually
ended up where we decided that,

151
00:08:37.890 --> 00:08:44.230
that is the technology we're going to use,
but my database is already 300 gigs.

152
00:08:44.230 --> 00:08:47.350
This process is probably gonna
take a bit longer, right?

153
00:08:48.370 --> 00:08:49.565
>> Yeah,
this process can take quite awhile.

154
00:08:49.565 --> 00:08:51.949
You want to plan for it.

155
00:08:51.949 --> 00:08:55.356
That'd be something you do in a change
window, set aside, a bunch of time.

156
00:08:55.356 --> 00:08:58.200
Because, it's gonna run through,
it's gonna take a little while.

157
00:08:58.200 --> 00:09:00.850
I made a pretty small drive here.

158
00:09:00.850 --> 00:09:04.387
There's nothing necessarily
to see after this, but

159
00:09:04.387 --> 00:09:09.741
I wanted to point out that lock icon and
then from here on out, that will be there.

160
00:09:09.741 --> 00:09:13.775
And it'll be easy for the administrators
to figure out if the drive's unlocked and

161
00:09:13.775 --> 00:09:14.530
what have you.

162
00:09:14.530 --> 00:09:16.770
>> All right, so
as long as everything is good,

163
00:09:16.770 --> 00:09:21.190
then we at least have a full
drive encryption that we can use.

164
00:09:21.190 --> 00:09:25.970
Really is something that's good and I
think Bitlocker's a pretty strong concept

165
00:09:25.970 --> 00:09:28.860
for us, in terms of a security strategy.

166
00:09:28.860 --> 00:09:32.660
Now the other one though, Brian,
is of course configuring S/MIME.

167
00:09:32.660 --> 00:09:36.630
If we've kind of been out of it a little
bit, remind us a little bit about S/MIME

168
00:09:36.630 --> 00:09:40.330
and then, what do we need to plan for
in terms of security?

169
00:09:40.330 --> 00:09:45.576
>> So S/MIME is an email encryption
approach that allows individual users

170
00:09:45.576 --> 00:09:50.650
to send encrypted email to other
users on the internet or internally.

171
00:09:50.650 --> 00:09:54.490
S/MIME is based on certificates.

172
00:09:54.490 --> 00:09:56.230
So in order to work with S/MIME,

173
00:09:56.230 --> 00:10:00.080
every user that uses it
needs to have a certificate.

174
00:10:00.080 --> 00:10:03.220
And that certificate needs to be trusted,
at a minimum,

175
00:10:03.220 --> 00:10:06.530
by all the people they're
gonna send the email to.

176
00:10:06.530 --> 00:10:10.510
So in general, the recommendation is
to use a third party certificate,

177
00:10:10.510 --> 00:10:15.440
something that's trusted,
probably by a provider that's well known.

178
00:10:15.440 --> 00:10:18.830
And you can acquire these certificates
from all of the providers.

179
00:10:18.830 --> 00:10:21.560
We're gonna walk through
the step-by-step process.

180
00:10:21.560 --> 00:10:24.799
And I'm gonna point out a couple
of key facts along the way.

181
00:10:24.799 --> 00:10:27.800
>> Sounds like a great idea,
let's go ahead and do that.

182
00:10:27.800 --> 00:10:32.393
>> So
we're gonna move over to Client One, and

183
00:10:32.393 --> 00:10:39.610
I'm logged on as Jack Jackson, and
I'm gonna walk through the MMC.

184
00:10:39.610 --> 00:10:43.148
We're gonna open up
the certificate snap-in,

185
00:10:43.148 --> 00:10:48.580
and the certificate snap-in,
want to add remove a snap-in.

186
00:10:48.580 --> 00:10:51.709
The certificate snap-in for
the user account.

187
00:10:56.207 --> 00:10:59.980
And, here's the certificate store for
jack.jackson.

188
00:10:59.980 --> 00:11:04.700
I've already acquired a certificate for
jack.jackson, so

189
00:11:04.700 --> 00:11:06.150
we can walk through this demo.

190
00:11:06.150 --> 00:11:07.440
And, I want to point something out for

191
00:11:07.440 --> 00:11:09.970
those of you that wanna walk
through this in your home lab.

192
00:11:09.970 --> 00:11:15.110
This is a free certificate,
it took about three minutes to acquire.

193
00:11:15.110 --> 00:11:17.472
There is a couple of providers out there,
one of them is name is Komodo.

194
00:11:17.472 --> 00:11:20.040
You can get a free email certificate.

195
00:11:20.040 --> 00:11:22.600
They're fully secured,
they're just like one you'd buy.

196
00:11:22.600 --> 00:11:27.340
It is very quick and easy to install and
it'll let you walk through S/MIME stuff.

197
00:11:27.340 --> 00:11:31.085
I've got that certificate, you can see
it's here, valid from 3/14 to next year.

198
00:11:31.085 --> 00:11:34.320
It's a one year certificate.

199
00:11:34.320 --> 00:11:38.720
Once I've got that in place, Outlook
knows to look in the users store for

200
00:11:38.720 --> 00:11:39.535
the certificate.

201
00:11:39.535 --> 00:11:43.660
And if you've got one you're now
capable of sending S/MIME email.

202
00:11:43.660 --> 00:11:45.480
So let's take a closer look at that.

203
00:11:49.010 --> 00:11:54.668
So before we get into the Outlook stuff,
I wanna walk through the process.

204
00:11:54.668 --> 00:11:57.590
And I'm hoping that I can describe it
in a way that's easy to understand.

205
00:11:57.590 --> 00:12:01.290
If we need to, we can always bring
out the virtual white board.

206
00:12:01.290 --> 00:12:02.560
So here's the process,

207
00:12:02.560 --> 00:12:07.030
I'm gonna say that Ronnie and I wanna
send each other an encrypted email.

208
00:12:07.030 --> 00:12:11.040
We each acquire a certificate,
we install it on our computers.

209
00:12:11.040 --> 00:12:13.605
We then cannot send each
other encrypted email yet.

210
00:12:13.605 --> 00:12:15.220
Here's how the process works.

211
00:12:15.220 --> 00:12:20.568
We each have to generate a new email
to each other and we have to sign it.

212
00:12:20.568 --> 00:12:23.390
So with S/MIME you can sign,
which is saying,

213
00:12:23.390 --> 00:12:29.410
hey this email is certainly from me or you
can encrypt, which protects all the data.

214
00:12:29.410 --> 00:12:32.710
In high security situations
you wanna sign and encrypt.

215
00:12:32.710 --> 00:12:35.970
So our first step is I'm gonna
send Ronnie a signed email and

216
00:12:35.970 --> 00:12:37.800
he's gonna send me an assigned email.

217
00:12:37.800 --> 00:12:41.580
When we get those emails, we're gonna
right click on each other's names,

218
00:12:41.580 --> 00:12:44.490
and add each other to our contact list.

219
00:12:44.490 --> 00:12:49.630
That's gonna enable Outlook to associate
the public side of the certificate

220
00:12:49.630 --> 00:12:53.230
to my Outlook, which allows me
to send him an encrypted email.

221
00:12:53.230 --> 00:12:56.220
So I'm gonna show you
that process right now.

222
00:12:56.220 --> 00:12:58.250
We're gonna generate a new email.

223
00:12:59.280 --> 00:13:02.550
And I'll make this a little smaller,
so we can zoom in along the way.

224
00:13:04.730 --> 00:13:09.494
And for now, I am going to send
this to Brian Svidergol, and

225
00:13:09.494 --> 00:13:11.892
I'll just say signed email.

226
00:13:11.892 --> 00:13:17.610
So that way they know to use this
one to start our S/MIME process.

227
00:13:17.610 --> 00:13:19.133
I'm gonna then click on Options.

228
00:13:19.133 --> 00:13:27.170
And you can see we have some options here,
Sign and Encrypt.

229
00:13:27.170 --> 00:13:30.278
The only we need at
the beginning is the Sign.

230
00:13:30.278 --> 00:13:32.454
So I'm gonna go ahead and click Sign,

231
00:13:32.454 --> 00:13:34.978
which only works if you
have a certificate.

232
00:13:34.978 --> 00:13:38.690
I'm gonna send that email off.

233
00:13:40.490 --> 00:13:44.810
Now for demonstration purposes,
I've already got one of these messages

234
00:13:44.810 --> 00:13:48.675
that I received earlier, and
let me take a look at that.

235
00:13:50.310 --> 00:13:54.870
So this email came in from one of
my email addresses where I have

236
00:13:54.870 --> 00:13:56.600
another certificate.

237
00:13:56.600 --> 00:13:59.870
And in the bottom right-hand side,
over here,

238
00:13:59.870 --> 00:14:04.810
of the email message, you get this
little signed email indication.

239
00:14:04.810 --> 00:14:07.459
Wanna show you what happens
if you click on it.

240
00:14:08.930 --> 00:14:14.190
We're gonna click on the details and
what it shows you is who sent this email.

241
00:14:14.190 --> 00:14:18.160
In this case brian@a1b2c3llc.com,

242
00:14:18.160 --> 00:14:22.690
that's the signer, and
we also have the certificate.

243
00:14:22.690 --> 00:14:25.802
So when I first got this email,

244
00:14:25.802 --> 00:14:30.940
I right-clicked on his name and
I added him to the contacts.

245
00:14:30.940 --> 00:14:34.365
Now I've just got edit contact,
but normally I'd have add.

246
00:14:34.365 --> 00:14:37.840
Thereafter, I can send
him an encrypted email.

247
00:14:37.840 --> 00:14:40.290
When he gets mine,
he does the same process and

248
00:14:40.290 --> 00:14:42.400
he can send me an encrypted email.

249
00:14:42.400 --> 00:14:46.140
So let me pause for a second Ronnie,
in case, I know I've said a lot but

250
00:14:46.140 --> 00:14:47.110
I still have more to say.

251
00:14:47.110 --> 00:14:48.414
I wanna see if there's any questions so
far.

252
00:14:48.414 --> 00:14:51.500
>> So far it looks like
the processing is very good.

253
00:14:51.500 --> 00:14:53.470
Let's make sure that we understand.

254
00:14:53.470 --> 00:14:55.864
First of all of course, we need to
make sure that we have a certificate.

255
00:14:55.864 --> 00:15:00.622
And then once, we do to begin the process
each person holding that certificate

256
00:15:00.622 --> 00:15:04.097
needs to at least exchange
a signed email to get started.

257
00:15:04.097 --> 00:15:08.540
And once that's actually done,
you'll add them to the contact list.

258
00:15:08.540 --> 00:15:11.590
From that point we are now
ready to send encrypted emails.

259
00:15:12.950 --> 00:15:13.650
>> You nailed it Ronnie.

260
00:15:13.650 --> 00:15:16.660
So let's take a look at
the encryption piece now.

261
00:15:16.660 --> 00:15:21.520
So now that I've got Brian here,
in my contacts,

262
00:15:21.520 --> 00:15:26.496
when I go to send an email,
super sensitive email,

263
00:15:26.496 --> 00:15:30.460
we're gonna go back to the Options tab.

264
00:15:30.460 --> 00:15:35.160
And now,
we're gonna use the Encrypt option.

265
00:15:35.160 --> 00:15:37.650
We can also do the Sign option too.

266
00:15:37.650 --> 00:15:38.746
But I wanna just show you both of these.

267
00:15:38.746 --> 00:15:43.129
When we do Sign and Encrypt,
we will go ahead and hit Send.

268
00:15:43.129 --> 00:15:46.910
I just wanna to show
you what it looks here.

269
00:15:46.910 --> 00:15:52.569
So, we are gonna zoom back in and
we now have two different icons over here.

270
00:15:52.569 --> 00:15:56.731
We've got a lock, that indicates that
the data is encrypted and secure.

271
00:15:56.731 --> 00:16:00.784
And, then we've got the little I call
that like a gold medal ribbon, and

272
00:16:00.784 --> 00:16:04.714
that indicates that it's actually
been signed, so now we have both.

273
00:16:04.714 --> 00:16:08.971
>> All right Brian, so
that sounds simple enough, you know,

274
00:16:08.971 --> 00:16:14.230
to actually get the emails encrypted,
so do we have anything else?

275
00:16:14.230 --> 00:16:15.906
>> Yeah, couple more things.

276
00:16:15.906 --> 00:16:20.105
I wanted to show, we showed you how to
sign and encrypt, and I'm looking at

277
00:16:20.105 --> 00:16:24.656
an email here, there's a small menu item,
let me make this smaller and zoom in.

278
00:16:24.656 --> 00:16:29.778
Where you can look at some of
the details of the configuration, and

279
00:16:29.778 --> 00:16:34.640
it's under the Tags menu,
with this little arrow right here.

280
00:16:34.640 --> 00:16:39.829
It's going to be tough to see once
I scroll back out and click it.

281
00:16:40.860 --> 00:16:41.800
And when you come in here,

282
00:16:41.800 --> 00:16:45.670
you can go to security settings,
and let's bring that back in.

283
00:16:46.760 --> 00:16:51.700
So here are the Security Properties,
you have a chain settings area.

284
00:16:51.700 --> 00:16:56.330
So if you had multiple
certificates on here, or if

285
00:16:56.330 --> 00:17:00.450
you wanted to do like a request nest mind
receipt for the message, there's a couple,

286
00:17:00.450 --> 00:17:03.979
just more options here to manage this
stuff and look at some of the details.

287
00:17:05.820 --> 00:17:10.587
Beyond that, I think the last thing
I wanna talk about is the impact

288
00:17:10.587 --> 00:17:14.850
of S/MIME to the administration portion,
right?

289
00:17:14.850 --> 00:17:18.220
So, there's a bunch of different
technologies out there to do secure email,

290
00:17:18.220 --> 00:17:20.740
encrypted email, S/MIME being one of them.

291
00:17:20.740 --> 00:17:24.630
It's a multi-platform, you know,
tool agnostic technology,

292
00:17:24.630 --> 00:17:26.820
been around a very long time.

293
00:17:26.820 --> 00:17:30.710
What's nice about it is,
users can do it all by themselves.

294
00:17:30.710 --> 00:17:32.920
Go out and acquire their own
free certificate, install it,

295
00:17:32.920 --> 00:17:35.990
it doesn't require any rights,
and just start encrypting email.

296
00:17:35.990 --> 00:17:39.010
But that's a problem sometimes in
a security organization, right?

297
00:17:39.010 --> 00:17:42.320
Because the IT staff doesn't know
anything about the certificate,

298
00:17:42.320 --> 00:17:45.390
they don't know what's being sent
out via that encrypted email, and

299
00:17:45.390 --> 00:17:49.290
most of their security software is
going to be totally in the dark.

300
00:17:49.290 --> 00:17:53.440
So, normally email encryption is
something, it's centrally handled,

301
00:17:53.440 --> 00:17:57.070
centrally managed, and
you know, supported by IT.

302
00:17:57.070 --> 00:17:59.890
So, that's one of the considerations.

303
00:17:59.890 --> 00:18:03.700
Later we're going to talk about
a different option, using

304
00:18:03.700 --> 00:18:08.330
Wright's Management Services and IRM,
that's sort of a competitor to S/MIME.

305
00:18:08.330 --> 00:18:12.771
So I wanted to point out some of the
deficiencies of S/MIME, so that as we go

306
00:18:12.771 --> 00:18:17.366
into these next topics, you'll kind
of be familiar with contrasting them.

307
00:18:17.366 --> 00:18:21.115
>> Now, Brian, talking about
that administrative side then,

308
00:18:21.115 --> 00:18:24.287
is there a way that we can
do some maybe group policy,

309
00:18:24.287 --> 00:18:27.360
that helps us to block
something like this?

310
00:18:27.360 --> 00:18:30.130
So somebody doesn't just put
a certificate on there and go,

311
00:18:30.130 --> 00:18:33.560
I'm gonna encrypt all of my
emails that I've been sending or

312
00:18:33.560 --> 00:18:37.710
been receiving,
in case that person gets let go.

313
00:18:37.710 --> 00:18:40.930
So is there something we can
do to help control that?

314
00:18:42.100 --> 00:18:44.460
>> Yeah,
there are a couple of things you can do.

315
00:18:44.460 --> 00:18:46.810
They're not all that easy, I mean.

316
00:18:46.810 --> 00:18:50.590
First, part of it's gonna depend on
whether your users have administrative

317
00:18:50.590 --> 00:18:53.190
rights to their computer,
that's one big one.

318
00:18:53.190 --> 00:18:58.720
Second, we do have group policy settings
that we can use to control Outlook,

319
00:18:58.720 --> 00:19:02.525
and the Office suite, and then third,
we can make do transport rules and

320
00:19:02.525 --> 00:19:03.575
some monitoring.

321
00:19:03.575 --> 00:19:07.815
So, we can at least be aware of,
if there's encrypted emails going out.

322
00:19:07.815 --> 00:19:09.295
For instance, in security software,

323
00:19:09.295 --> 00:19:13.155
any virus software,
stuff that scans messages for compliance.

324
00:19:13.155 --> 00:19:14.945
Those are gonna be all left in the dark.

325
00:19:14.945 --> 00:19:17.655
A lot of times you can configure
those pieces of software

326
00:19:17.655 --> 00:19:22.520
to alert the administrator if email is
going about that it can't scan, and

327
00:19:22.520 --> 00:19:25.260
you wanna aware of that staff.

328
00:19:25.260 --> 00:19:30.100
And then final thought here, I know is a
lot of information, but in a high security

329
00:19:30.100 --> 00:19:35.180
organisation, where there is maybe
one person, maybe it's somebody

330
00:19:35.180 --> 00:19:39.262
on the legal team, or somebody else that's
doing something very, very, sensitive.

331
00:19:39.262 --> 00:19:42.120
Sometimes S/MIME is the right solution,

332
00:19:42.120 --> 00:19:47.550
where even IT can't get in the data,
so keep that in mind.

333
00:19:47.550 --> 00:19:51.000
>> Alright, Brian, well thank you again
for helping us to think about the way to

334
00:19:51.000 --> 00:19:56.210
plan out a type of security strategy
that we can actually use for Exchange.

335
00:19:56.210 --> 00:19:58.075
Remember that when we took
a look at that here, of course,

336
00:19:58.075 --> 00:20:02.290
is the idea of actually implementing
BitLocker for a full drive encryption.

337
00:20:02.290 --> 00:20:06.620
Brian did show us again, that when
the keys, if we have to use a password,

338
00:20:06.620 --> 00:20:09.730
is to make sure that we have
that stored in a secure place.

339
00:20:09.730 --> 00:20:13.950
And, Brian, actually,
one of our chat viewers mentioned,

340
00:20:13.950 --> 00:20:19.088
don't forget that we can actually use our
domain, or our active directory network,

341
00:20:19.088 --> 00:20:22.630
so that BitLocker recovery keys can
also be stored in the active directory.

342
00:20:22.630 --> 00:20:25.730
So, that's a good reminder
to think about as well.

343
00:20:25.730 --> 00:20:27.550
And then of course, the use of S/MIME.

344
00:20:27.550 --> 00:20:30.260
Brian took us through an example
of how to get that set-up, but

345
00:20:30.260 --> 00:20:33.080
as well as told us that
the benefits to that, and

346
00:20:33.080 --> 00:20:35.920
as well as the warning,
especially on the administration side.

347
00:20:35.920 --> 00:20:40.740
And you can imagine, that if there is a
disgruntled worker that decides, you know,

348
00:20:40.740 --> 00:20:44.310
from now on I'm just gonna encrypt every
single piece of mail that I get, and

349
00:20:44.310 --> 00:20:47.880
if I get let go, the only way that I can
get to it is if they come and beg me.

350
00:20:47.880 --> 00:20:52.520
Well, that can be a problem as well, so,
you know, be aware, but at the same time

351
00:20:52.520 --> 00:20:55.890
you may find that there is a particular
reason to allow that to happen, and

352
00:20:55.890 --> 00:20:56.614
it is the right reason.

353
00:20:56.614 --> 00:20:58.400
So make sure you hang out to that too.

354
00:20:58.400 --> 00:21:00.540
All right Brian, thank you again, for

355
00:21:00.540 --> 00:21:06.070
helping us to think of these two topics,
in a way, especially dealing with email.

356
00:21:06.070 --> 00:21:08.525
And thank you, also, for watching.

357
00:21:08.525 --> 00:21:11.700
Signing-off for ITProTV,
I have been your host Ronnie Wong.

358
00:21:11.700 --> 00:21:12.840
>> And I am Brian Svidergol.

359
00:21:12.840 --> 00:21:16.089
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Exchange 2016 shows.

360
00:21:16.089 --> 00:21:22.270
[MUSIC]

361
00:21:22.270 --> 00:21:26.075
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie introduce the topic of Information Rights Management and the implementation using AD Rights Management and Azure RMS.  Brian also describes the difference between these two implementation. Next Brian takes us through using RMS Templates as the basis for setting up Rights Management in the Exchange Admin Center. He demonstrates Transport Protection Rules and describes how this used to protect our email after it’s sent outbound. The guys contrast that withOutlook Protection rules which protects messages before the arrive in the mailbox.  Brian also reviews  journal report decryption, eDiscovery, pre-licensing.  They end episode reviewing the troubleshooting tools and where to begin.
episodes.title: IRM with AD Rights Mgmt and Azure RMS

topics.title: Plan, deploy, and manage an Exchange infrastructure, recipients, and security

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at implementing the DLP according to a business need.  They describe the concept and the use of templates as a starting point.  They show the default templates and how to implement them.  Also described by the guys is the ability to customize rules and set policies for the DLP.  Brian then also demonstrates how to create a blank template that has to be manually configured too.  Lastly, they complete the topic by demonstrating Exchange DLP thumbprinting for the company data that is not part of the normal of the PII information covered.
episodes.title: Data Loss Prevention DLP

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss and demonstrate Exchange 2016 archiving and MRM.  They show how to configure retention polices and create custom tag, then associate them together to be applied to users.  Brian demonstrates how the policies are applied by the Managed Folder Assistant and how to remove and delete tags.  The guys discuss the idea of using online archiving such as Office 365, mentioning the perquisites and considerations.  Lastly they create archive policies and configure in-place archiving.
episodes.title: Archiving and MRM
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:04.687
I'm your host, Don [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:04.687 --> 00:00:08.590
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:08.590 --> 00:00:15.760
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.760 --> 00:00:20.430
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today,
you're watching a show on configuring and

6
00:00:20.430 --> 00:00:24.160
managing archiving And
message records management.

7
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:25.760
That's quite a mouthful Brian.

8
00:00:25.760 --> 00:00:29.480
When we start to take a look at this we
need of course a better understanding and

9
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:33.140
that's why we have our exchange expert
right here, Mr. Brian Swedergahl.

10
00:00:33.140 --> 00:00:36.700
Brian, welcome to our show and
help us out with this topic here.

11
00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:37.850
How are we going to begin?

12
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:38.810
>> Sure.

13
00:00:38.810 --> 00:00:40.970
So MRM for

14
00:00:40.970 --> 00:00:44.820
short, that's a little bit easier to say,
is about trying to figure out

15
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:48.260
what you want to do with all of that email
data that's coming into your organization.

16
00:00:48.260 --> 00:00:52.050
Some companies choose to do nothing with
it, let the user decide whether they're

17
00:00:52.050 --> 00:00:55.970
going to keep it or delete it, and then
you have some users keep things forever.

18
00:00:55.970 --> 00:01:00.110
And then you have some users that
archive it off to PST files or

19
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:01.420
something like that.

20
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:08.790
So MRM is really centralizing the choice
of what you do with all that email data.

21
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:09.880
And in many organizations,

22
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:13.750
there's some sort of legal mandate,
there could be some compliance situation

23
00:01:13.750 --> 00:01:18.250
that dictates that you need to keep all
email for a certain period of time.

24
00:01:18.250 --> 00:01:22.740
And in other organizations,
not quite as many There's

25
00:01:22.740 --> 00:01:27.210
another mandate that says well,
we're only going to keep email for

26
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:31.390
say two years and our policy is
everything gets deleted after that.

27
00:01:31.390 --> 00:01:34.050
So MOM can help us do those things.

28
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:37.840
Today we are going to start
with retention policies.

29
00:01:37.840 --> 00:01:40.770
And you're going to see that these
topics sort of build on each other.

30
00:01:40.770 --> 00:01:43.280
So we're going to start
with retention policies

31
00:01:43.280 --> 00:01:48.190
Tension policies are basically
a collection of tags and

32
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:51.590
tags are what dictate what we're
gonna do with that email data.

33
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:55.670
So let's go and get started right
here at the PowerShell prompt and

34
00:01:55.670 --> 00:01:57.458
show you how to work with these things.
