them up in Office 365.

258
00:16:17.930 --> 00:16:19.600
And you can mix and match.

259
00:16:19.600 --> 00:16:22.780
So you can have a primary
mailbox on-premises and

260
00:16:22.780 --> 00:16:25.210
an archive mailbox in Office 365.

261
00:16:25.210 --> 00:16:28.150
That offloads a lot of
the storage consideration.

262
00:16:29.340 --> 00:16:32.565
But to do that,
let's talk through those requirements.

263
00:16:32.565 --> 00:16:35.410
So there are two main requirements really.

264
00:16:35.410 --> 00:16:39.290
We need to be in a hybrid
configuration with Office 365.

265
00:16:39.290 --> 00:16:42.950
We're gonna talk a little bit about
the hybrid configuration in later topics.

266
00:16:42.950 --> 00:16:44.198
I don't know if that's today or tomorrow.

267
00:16:44.198 --> 00:16:45.900
So stay tuned for that.

268
00:16:45.900 --> 00:16:48.950
But the hybrid configuration
requires two things.

269
00:16:48.950 --> 00:16:55.630
You need to have direct resynchronization
and an organization relationship.

270
00:16:55.630 --> 00:16:58.641
And I think we'll cover both those
topics as well in the near future.

271
00:16:58.641 --> 00:17:00.179
So stay tuned for those.

272
00:17:01.350 --> 00:17:05.045
>> All right, so what are some additional
considerations that we have to think about

273
00:17:05.045 --> 00:17:10.360
of whether we're gonna archive the mailbox
on-premises or going into the cloud?

274
00:17:10.360 --> 00:17:12.690
So how do we decide which
one's gonna be best for us?

275
00:17:13.760 --> 00:17:19.160
>> Yeah, the number one thing I think
about is the consumption of bandwidth.

276
00:17:19.160 --> 00:17:22.198
There's two key considerations
with the bandwidth.

277
00:17:22.198 --> 00:17:26.870
One is when you first put your
archive mailboxes in the cloud.

278
00:17:26.870 --> 00:17:29.720
If you've got a couple thousand users and
you put a couple thousand archive

279
00:17:29.720 --> 00:17:34.140
mailboxes out in the cloud, how much data
do you need to get out there initially?

280
00:17:34.140 --> 00:17:39.070
How long is that gonna take and
how impactful that gonna be

281
00:17:39.070 --> 00:17:40.150
to your environment?

282
00:17:40.150 --> 00:17:44.790
And then ongoing, how much data are you
sending to the archive mailboxes?

283
00:17:44.790 --> 00:17:51.020
In some organizations, every time a new
email comes in, an old email goes out.

284
00:17:51.020 --> 00:17:54.389
And so in a situation like that with
archive mailboxes in the cloud,

285
00:17:54.389 --> 00:17:56.720
it can be fairly bandwidth intensive.

286
00:17:56.720 --> 00:18:00.349
So you wanna take that into consideration
as you're going through your planning.

287
00:18:01.600 --> 00:18:05.560
>> Now, once we have everything configured
for the MRM the way that we need to.

288
00:18:05.560 --> 00:18:10.566
Does this just work or is there any other
things that we have to worry about?

289
00:18:10.566 --> 00:18:18.430
>> So I think you might be alluding to our
next topic, which is archive policies.

290
00:18:18.430 --> 00:18:21.400
And so far, we've talked about MRM.

291
00:18:21.400 --> 00:18:25.500
And we've talked really about retention
holds, deleting items and stuff.

292
00:18:25.500 --> 00:18:27.957
But now we're getting
more into the archiving.

293
00:18:27.957 --> 00:18:30.418
Which is, hey,
we wanna keep messages around.

294
00:18:30.418 --> 00:18:33.100
And we wanna keep them in
our archive mailboxes.

295
00:18:33.100 --> 00:18:36.549
So let's take a look at the computer and
see how we can work with these things.

296
00:18:41.663 --> 00:18:43.634
Let's clear this.

297
00:18:43.634 --> 00:18:49.856
We're gonna go
New-RetentionPolicyTag Name.

298
00:18:49.856 --> 00:18:55.263
And we're gonna go Jack's archive tag,
a personal tag.

299
00:18:55.263 --> 00:19:00.520
-Type All AgeLimitForRetention 365.

300
00:19:00.520 --> 00:19:05.080
But this time,
we're gonna do the MoveToArchive.

301
00:19:05.080 --> 00:19:08.300
If you remember earlier,
I talked about there being three actions.

302
00:19:08.300 --> 00:19:10.170
One was a permanent deletion.

303
00:19:10.170 --> 00:19:13.360
One was a deletion but allow recovery.

304
00:19:13.360 --> 00:19:15.390
This is that third one, MoveToArchive.

305
00:19:15.390 --> 00:19:19.834
And this action is what dictates
that these are archive policies.

306
00:19:19.834 --> 00:19:22.560
So that's the differentiator there.

307
00:19:22.560 --> 00:19:27.021
So that is now in place, RetentionPolicy.

308
00:19:27.021 --> 00:19:36.660
We're gonna call this
RetentionPolicy-Archive for Jack.

309
00:19:36.660 --> 00:19:41.420
RetentionPolicyTagLinks, this should look
semi familiar to you guys from earlier.

310
00:19:41.420 --> 00:19:43.940
So we're associating the policy
with the policy tag.

311
00:19:43.940 --> 00:19:50.957
And then, finally, we're gonna do
the Set-Mailbox Jack.Jackson so

312
00:19:50.957 --> 00:19:53.838
that we can apply this thing.

313
00:19:53.838 --> 00:19:59.369
RetentionPolicy, and then we specify

314
00:19:59.369 --> 00:20:05.920
the name RetentionPolicy-Archive-Jack.

315
00:20:05.920 --> 00:20:07.370
So there you have it.

316
00:20:07.370 --> 00:20:11.196
Archive policies, even though it
looks like a totally new thing,

317
00:20:11.196 --> 00:20:14.969
it's really a retention policy
with the move to archive action.

318
00:20:16.410 --> 00:20:18.260
>> Now,
when we start talking about archiving,

319
00:20:18.260 --> 00:20:23.010
we also still need to plan for
in-place archiving as well.

320
00:20:23.010 --> 00:20:23.851
And Brian, you're gonna help

321
00:20:23.851 --> 00:20:25.250
us to understand this a little bit better,
right?

322
00:20:27.420 --> 00:20:30.840
>> Yes, I am, so
here's the interesting thing.

323
00:20:30.840 --> 00:20:35.920
We've created a policy that says, hey,
archive items based on this configuration.

324
00:20:35.920 --> 00:20:39.150
But we also actually
need archive mailboxes.

325
00:20:39.150 --> 00:20:42.400
And up till now,
we've been working with primary mailboxes.

326
00:20:42.400 --> 00:20:44.375
But there's the concept
of an archive mailbox.

327
00:20:44.375 --> 00:20:50.210
Which is a secondary mailbox specifically
set up to take on these archive messages.

328
00:20:50.210 --> 00:20:52.150
So let's drop down to the computer and
take a look.

329
00:20:55.723 --> 00:20:58.130
So let me clear this.

330
00:20:58.130 --> 00:20:59.820
We're gonna do an Enable-Mailbox.

331
00:20:59.820 --> 00:21:02.160
You guys might remember
this cmdlet from yesterday.

332
00:21:03.390 --> 00:21:05.600
In this case, we're gonna go Ken.Jones.

333
00:21:05.600 --> 00:21:07.520
And we're gonna specify Archive.

334
00:21:09.925 --> 00:21:13.795
There it is, Archive.

335
00:21:13.795 --> 00:21:14.940
Ken.Jones couldn't be found.

336
00:21:16.100 --> 00:21:21.294
Well, let's do a get-mailbox and
find another candidate.

337
00:21:23.659 --> 00:21:24.823
Aha, there is Ken.

338
00:21:24.823 --> 00:21:29.272
So Ken Jones actually is Ken and
not Ken.Jones in my standard.

339
00:21:29.272 --> 00:21:32.380
I went away from my corporate standards,
not cool.

340
00:21:33.540 --> 00:21:39.950
Let's try this again with just
the actual alias name for Ken.

341
00:21:39.950 --> 00:21:40.919
And that works.

342
00:21:40.919 --> 00:21:44.130
So I should change that later maybe.

343
00:21:44.130 --> 00:21:47.510
So now, Ken's got an archive mailbox.

344
00:21:47.510 --> 00:21:50.230
Let's take a look at
viewing that real quick.

345
00:21:51.980 --> 00:21:55.280
We're gonna look at archive specifically.

346
00:21:56.320 --> 00:22:00.460
And so you can see we didn't
specify an archive database.

347
00:22:00.460 --> 00:22:01.850
So it picked one out, DB10.

348
00:22:02.910 --> 00:22:06.340
And it shows you the in-place
archive right there is the name.

349
00:22:06.340 --> 00:22:12.020
And then it has the default quota on
there, 100 GB with the warning at 90 GB.

350
00:22:12.020 --> 00:22:14.069
You can change that,
but that's the default.

351
00:22:15.160 --> 00:22:20.090
And then, finally, I'll show you, you
can view all of the archive mailboxes in

352
00:22:20.090 --> 00:22:25.227
the organization by just doing
the get-mailbox -Archive.

353
00:22:25.227 --> 00:22:27.740
And that archive specification,

354
00:22:27.740 --> 00:22:33.030
it's the same thing that we saw
earlier with public folder or others.

355
00:22:33.030 --> 00:22:33.960
It's fairly flexible.

356
00:22:35.010 --> 00:22:39.640
>> All right, well, Brian, I believe
that that's actually the last topic that

357
00:22:39.640 --> 00:22:43.860
we need to cover in this particular
section of taking a look at the MRM and

358
00:22:43.860 --> 00:22:45.340
the archiving here.

359
00:22:45.340 --> 00:22:50.055
Remember that what you took a look at in
this episode is to talk about the idea

360
00:22:50.055 --> 00:22:53.905
of configuring, of course, the retention
policies and planning for them.

361
00:22:53.905 --> 00:22:57.862
Brian also emphasized the fact that not
only do we need to create those policies,

362
00:22:57.862 --> 00:22:59.910
but the tags, associate them together.

363
00:22:59.910 --> 00:23:01.175
And then, of course,

364
00:23:01.175 --> 00:23:06.090
make sure that users have access to them
by associating those together as well.

365
00:23:06.090 --> 00:23:10.750
He also helped us here in taking a look
at the managed folder assistant.

366
00:23:10.750 --> 00:23:14.500
And getting that ready to work
with what we were talking about.

367
00:23:14.500 --> 00:23:18.390
As well as how to remove those tags and
delete those tags when we need to, too.

368
00:23:18.390 --> 00:23:20.970
And then because of the way
that the world is going.

369
00:23:20.970 --> 00:23:25.653
And Office 365 is a consideration for
moving or archiving there or

370
00:23:25.653 --> 00:23:27.033
to somewhere else.

371
00:23:27.033 --> 00:23:29.820
Remember that we want
to take look at that.

372
00:23:29.820 --> 00:23:30.480
As well as,

373
00:23:30.480 --> 00:23:35.530
of course, creating some different
archive policies that we have in place.

374
00:23:35.530 --> 00:23:38.860
As well as configuring
the in-place archiving.

375
00:23:38.860 --> 00:23:44.250
Which is storing that archive along with
the mailbox, if I remember correctly.

376
00:23:44.250 --> 00:23:46.500
So there's a lot of information here.

377
00:23:46.500 --> 00:23:50.030
Now, Brian, again, since we have
just a couple of minutes here.

378
00:23:50.030 --> 00:23:51.980
When it comes down to getting ready for

379
00:23:51.980 --> 00:23:56.510
the exam, best way to try and
practice some of these things.

380
00:23:56.510 --> 00:24:02.384
What do we need to think about in terms of
just getting this set into our minds and

381
00:24:02.384 --> 00:24:03.900
ready for the exam?

382
00:24:03.900 --> 00:24:09.980
>> Yeah, this is one of those
topics that's tough in a home lab.

383
00:24:09.980 --> 00:24:13.150
However, if you do have a home lab you
can certainly flip this stuff on and

384
00:24:13.150 --> 00:24:14.280
go through it.

385
00:24:14.280 --> 00:24:19.310
If you don't, in Office 365,
at least from the end user perspective,

386
00:24:19.310 --> 00:24:22.810
you can gain access to some
of the MRM available there.

387
00:24:22.810 --> 00:24:26.347
And work with it from an end
user perspective in Outlook and

388
00:24:26.347 --> 00:24:27.726
see how it functions.

389
00:24:27.726 --> 00:24:30.261
So that can be helpful for the exam.

390
00:24:30.261 --> 00:24:36.380
>> All right, well, that's a great place
for us to also end this episode then.

391
00:24:36.380 --> 00:24:40.360
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

392
00:24:40.360 --> 00:24:41.630
>> And I"m Brian Svidergol.

393
00:24:41.630 --> 00:24:44.460
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Exchange 2016 shows.

394
00:24:44.460 --> 00:24:52.212
[MUSIC]

395
00:24:52.212 --> 00:24:54.607
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie cover using eDiscovery.  They emphasize the need of using the RBAC role for eDiscovery.  They configure a litigation hold on a mailbox to show how it can be used, these hold can take up to 60 minutes to be enabled or disabled.  Brian performs a query-based InPlace hold on a single mailbox and then multiple-mailbox discovery.  Last topic the guys cover is working with Microsoft Sharepoint’s Discovery to do a federated search.
episodes.title: Plan Configure and Perform eDiscovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:04.853
Welcome to ITPRO.TV I'm
your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.853 --> 00:00:06.778
>> [MUSIC]

3
00:00:06.778 --> 00:00:12.760
Your watching ITPRO.TV
>> Welcome

4
00:00:12.760 --> 00:00:16.000
to another great episode
right here on ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:16.000 --> 00:00:20.600
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today
you’re watching the idea of planning and

6
00:00:20.600 --> 00:00:23.430
of course configuring and performing.

7
00:00:23.430 --> 00:00:28.230
ediscovery, and here to help us out is
our Exchange expert, Mr. Brian Svidergol.

8
00:00:28.230 --> 00:00:33.640
Brian, welcome to our show and
help us to get started here on ediscovery.

9
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:34.440
>> Sure, thanks, Ronnie.

10
00:00:34.440 --> 00:00:38.210
So ediscovery,
let's quickly define what it is.

11
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:40.340
Refresher for some of you.

12
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:43.980
So ediscovery enables administrators or

13
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.950
whoever else has been designated
the proper rights to be able

14
00:00:46.950 --> 00:00:52.210
to search all the organizations
mailboxes for specified data.

15
00:00:52.210 --> 00:00:57.510
It could be related to a legal case or
some kind of compliance search.

16
00:00:57.510 --> 00:00:59.750
It could be related to an audit.

17
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:04.630
Maybe a security incident, it's typically
one of those areas dictates, if somebody's

18
00:01:04.630 --> 00:01:08.790
gotta search the entire organization for
messages that meet certain criteria.

19
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:11.080
So that's the whole concept of eDiscovery.

20
00:01:11.080 --> 00:01:12.830
>> All right, so

21
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:17.580
Brian when we get into what types
of role based access control roles

22
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:22.290
do we need to make sure when we start
having to do something like eDiscovery?

23
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:25.510
And interesting thing with Exchange and
we've seen it a couple of times so far.

24
00:01:25.510 --> 00:01:29.410
Is that even though you might be
a full Exchange Administrator.

25
00:01:29.410 --> 00:01:32.830
There's certain tasks that
you can't do out of the box

26
00:01:32.830 --> 00:01:36.500
without using some of the built-in
rules that come with Exchange.

27
00:01:36.500 --> 00:01:38.670
So this happens to be one of them.

28
00:01:38.670 --> 00:01:42.850
You can't do E Discovery as a full
Exchange Administer instead

29
00:01:42.850 --> 00:01:45.950
you need to be designated a specific role.

30
00:01:45.950 --> 00:01:47.586
Lets take a look at how you can do that.

31
00:01:49.510 --> 00:01:54.240
We're gonna go to mailbox server number
one lets clear off the past stuff.

32
00:01:54.240 --> 00:02:01.920
And in this case we're gonna make Tom our
e-discovery guy, add role group member.

33
00:02:01.920 --> 00:02:07.630
Identity, the particular identity is
going to be Discovery Management,

34
00:02:07.630 --> 00:02:13.490
and that is what's gonna give
Tom everything he needs.

35
00:02:14.990 --> 00:02:15.880
Let's take a look here.

36
00:02:17.909 --> 00:02:21.190
Okay, so Add-RoleGroupMember.

37
00:02:21.190 --> 00:02:23.090
We've seen this one before.

38
00:02:23.090 --> 00:02:27.130
The only thing different here is that
we're specifying Discovery Management and

39
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:29.800
that one is key to performing e-discovery.

40
00:02:29.800 --> 00:02:34.380
So, at this point forward, Tom is now able
to do those searches we talked about.

41
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:38.500
Now Brian, we also then,
once we get this rolling [INAUDIBLE].

42
00:02:38.500 --> 00:02:44.440
We need to enable something that we call
a legal hold or a litigation hold here.

43
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:45.890
What is that about?

44
00:02:45.890 --> 00:02:46.960
>> So a legal hold or

45
00:02:46.960 --> 00:02:51.440
a litigation hold is,
let's pretend that you have a legal case.

46
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:55.060
There's something going on with
the organization, maybe there's a lawsuit.

47
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:59.250
And we find out maybe it's in
involving the sales organization.

48
00:02:59.250 --> 00:03:03.650
And so, the legal team at
the organization says, hey, listen.

49
00:03:03.650 --> 00:03:07.510
For right now, we need to place
all email data on hold for

50
00:03:07.510 --> 00:03:12.390
the sales organization so
that it can't be deleted, altered, or

51
00:03:12.390 --> 00:03:17.600
otherwise changed while we're
sorting through this Legal scenario.

52
00:03:17.600 --> 00:03:22.240
>> Now, Brian, in a previous episode, we
had just talked about retention policies.

53
00:03:22.240 --> 00:03:27.020
Is a legal hold a type of retention
policy, or is it something different?

54
00:03:27.020 --> 00:03:28.090
>> It's a little bit different.

55
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:33.090
Think of legal hold, and
now we're calling them litigation holds

56
00:03:33.090 --> 00:03:37.690
As a more serious and
more permanent type of hole.

57
00:03:37.690 --> 00:03:40.500
Retention is all about,
hey we want to keep this data around or

58
00:03:40.500 --> 00:03:43.550
we want to delete it,
maybe we want to archive it.

59
00:03:43.550 --> 00:03:47.080
On the label side it's really
we have to keep it around.

60
00:03:47.080 --> 00:03:52.180
And I want to point out something
about these illegal holds When you

61
00:03:52.180 --> 00:03:57.400
set a user for a legal hold, litigation
hold the user's totally unaware.

62
00:03:57.400 --> 00:04:01.020
So in the background we're
keeping all of that data

63
00:04:01.020 --> 00:04:03.120
based on the settings that we specify.

64
00:04:03.120 --> 00:04:08.080
Even if the users goes and deletes email
or tries to bypass any of the policies

65
00:04:08.080 --> 00:04:12.010
we put in place all that data's
gonna remain and we're good there.

66
00:04:13.520 --> 00:04:18.330
All right so Brian what do we need to do
to make sure that we've got this enabled

67
00:04:18.330 --> 00:04:19.460
when we're called upon to do it?

68
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:24.480
>> So let's take a look at
the PowerShell prompt here and,

69
00:04:24.480 --> 00:04:26.250
let's set somebody up for it.

70
00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:29.390
So Set-Mailbox,
we're gonna go back to our buddy Jack.

71
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:36.680
And we gonna reset mail box with the
litigation hold the enabled set to true.

72
00:04:36.680 --> 00:04:40.520
Now this particular command
will settle litigation hold for

73
00:04:40.520 --> 00:04:44.350
just Jack Jackson's mail box and
the hold is gonna be indefinite.

74
00:04:44.350 --> 00:04:50.800
You gonna see a warn that may take
up to 60 minutes to take effect.

75
00:04:50.800 --> 00:04:54.950
So be aware of that if
you know you hear some

76
00:04:54.950 --> 00:05:00.080
situations out there with an emergency
situation to get this holes in place,

77
00:05:00.080 --> 00:05:02.740
you might have the users
scrambling to get rid of the data,

78
00:05:02.740 --> 00:05:05.960
just be aware that it can take
60 minutes to take a fact.

79
00:05:05.960 --> 00:05:10.870
Now Brian since we just also
configured that I can't remember which

80
00:05:10.870 --> 00:05:15.630
account you configured for
the discovery management role.

81
00:05:15.630 --> 00:05:18.920
Do they have to actually be in that
group before you can run this command?

82
00:05:20.000 --> 00:05:22.980
>> So the command that we just ran,
the set-mailbox, no.

83
00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:27.600
That's gonna be the exchange
administrator that can run that command.

84
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:30.030
I wanna show you a couple more too.

85
00:05:30.030 --> 00:05:34.590
But Tom now is able to run
the eDiscovery searches unless he has

86
00:05:34.590 --> 00:05:38.080
specific exchange admin rights in
addition to discovery management,

of course, regulatory, or some type
of compliance issues that we have.

315
00:19:48.320 --> 00:19:50.120
So what Brian showed us here, of course,

316
00:19:50.120 --> 00:19:55.370
is that idea of being able to get
ready to do things like eDiscovery.

317
00:19:55.370 --> 00:19:58.510
Such as remembering that the user that's
gonna be doing this has to have that

318
00:19:58.510 --> 00:20:03.380
specific role based access control
of the discovery management.

319
00:20:03.380 --> 00:20:07.890
Make sure that user has that, and then we
also, of course, took a look at how we can

320
00:20:07.890 --> 00:20:14.920
enable a litigation hold, or a legal hold
on a particular user's mailbox as well.

321
00:20:14.920 --> 00:20:18.100
Brian also helped us to distinguish
the idea of a query based,

322
00:20:18.100 --> 00:20:22.970
in place hold, by limiting the parameters,
of course, to a search that we wanted,

323
00:20:22.970 --> 00:20:25.400
and make sure that was also in place.

324
00:20:25.400 --> 00:20:28.050
And then he also showed
us the ability to do

325
00:20:28.050 --> 00:20:31.920
these searches across multiple
mailboxes to do that.

326
00:20:31.920 --> 00:20:33.780
Now one question I did emphasize is that,

327
00:20:33.780 --> 00:20:36.370
does this actually require
a legal hold for us to do this?

328
00:20:36.370 --> 00:20:38.370
He said, not necessarily.

329
00:20:38.370 --> 00:20:41.400
Remember that all this can be done
without actually having a hold in place.

330
00:20:41.400 --> 00:20:42.910
So we should be fine with that too.

331
00:20:42.910 --> 00:20:46.170
And then lastly,
we did take a look here, or

332
00:20:46.170 --> 00:20:51.410
Brian did mention the idea of
using Share Point's discovery.

333
00:20:51.410 --> 00:20:54.390
Make sure that that is a part of it.

334
00:20:54.390 --> 00:20:58.430
And the idea of actually being able to run
this type of discovery through SharePoint

335
00:20:58.430 --> 00:21:01.250
is something that you may want
to be sure that you look into,

336
00:21:01.250 --> 00:21:03.940
especially in getting ready for the exam.

337
00:21:03.940 --> 00:21:07.030
Now Brian, on the eDiscovery side for
getting ready for

338
00:21:07.030 --> 00:21:09.970
the exam, this doesn't seem
like too much of a challenge.

339
00:21:09.970 --> 00:21:13.510
The commands that seem to be run,
don't look like it requires really any

340
00:21:13.510 --> 00:21:16.980
additional infrastructure, besides
what you can actually do in the lab.

341
00:21:16.980 --> 00:21:22.455
So any tricky things about this that
we might need to take a look at?

342
00:21:22.455 --> 00:21:27.200
>> Yeah, I think from the exam preparation
aspect, it's fairly straightforward, and

343
00:21:27.200 --> 00:21:29.280
it's also something you
can do in home lab,

344
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:31.560
or in a development environment at work.

345
00:21:31.560 --> 00:21:34.876
I will emphasize that
the tricky parts here,

346
00:21:34.876 --> 00:21:40.111
are figuring out whether you need a hold,
what kinda hold you need, for

347
00:21:40.111 --> 00:21:45.797
how long, how do you flip that stuff on,
and what the impacts are of the hold?

348
00:21:45.797 --> 00:21:49.989
And when we talked some of those little
details, like about the quotas, and

349
00:21:49.989 --> 00:21:52.890
where the information gets
sent in the eDiscovery.

350
00:21:52.890 --> 00:21:56.060
Those little details I think
might pop up on the exam.

351
00:21:57.220 --> 00:21:57.850
>> All right, Brian.

352
00:21:57.850 --> 00:22:01.770
Well thank you again for helping us
out in learning more about eDiscovery.

353
00:22:01.770 --> 00:22:03.850
And also thank you for watching.

354
00:22:03.850 --> 00:22:06.570
This is a great place for
us to go and sign off.

355
00:22:06.570 --> 00:22:09.553
For ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

356
00:22:09.553 --> 00:22:10.221
>> And I'm Brian Svidergol.

357
00:22:10.221 --> 00:22:16.854
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Exchange 2016 shows.

358
00:22:16.854 --> 00:22:21.261
[MUSIC]

359
00:22:21.261 --> 00:22:23.170
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie breakdown compliance tasks for Exchange 2016.  They configure MailTips and Message Classifications to help users with compliance.  Brian sets up the transport rules to limit the sending of messages and he takes a look at configuring journaling for compliance. Lastly, Brian addresses and demonstrates how to enable auditing for the mailbox owner and the exchange administrator.
episodes.title: Plan Configure and Manage Compliance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.074
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.074 --> 00:00:04.771
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.771 --> 00:00:06.646
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:06.646 --> 00:00:11.221
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.221 --> 00:00:14.930
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.930 --> 00:00:19.790
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,
you're watching planning, configuring, and

7
00:00:19.790 --> 00:00:20.430
managing.

8
00:00:20.430 --> 00:00:22.230
Well, compliance solutions.

9
00:00:22.230 --> 00:00:22.930
In Exchange 2016.

10
00:00:22.930 --> 00:00:27.410
And here to help us is our Exchange
expert Mr. Brian Svidergol.

11
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:29.140
Brian, welcome back to our show and

12
00:00:29.140 --> 00:00:32.470
tell us where we're gonna get
started in terms of compliance.

13
00:00:32.470 --> 00:00:33.450
>> Sure Ronnie.

14
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:38.120
So today we are gonna get started
on a topic named Mail Tips.

15
00:00:38.120 --> 00:00:43.270
And if you're not familiar with them,
mail tips are those little Status messages

16
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:48.310
that are displayed in outlook or
outlook on the web, that give you some

17
00:00:48.310 --> 00:00:53.350
sort of indication of either, you know
somebody is gone to office or there

18
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:57.710
is an issue sending to the user may be
they are on vacation, something like that.

19
00:00:57.710 --> 00:01:02.250
They can be used for
hopeful idea of purposes often for

20
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:07.550
notifying somebody of something permanent
to who they are sending to So very useful.

21
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:10.940
There are a couple of built-in ones, but

22
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:15.200
we're gonna really dive into how you
can customize them in your environment.

23
00:01:15.200 --> 00:01:15.780
>> All right, Brian.

24
00:01:15.780 --> 00:01:20.230
So when we start taking a look at this,
what do we need to do to get started

25
00:01:20.230 --> 00:01:23.161
when we actually want to make
something like a custom?

26
00:01:23.161 --> 00:01:25.130
And what do we need to do?

27
00:01:25.130 --> 00:01:27.870
So we're gonna get onto
mailbox server number one.

28
00:01:27.870 --> 00:01:29.910
And let's take a look at
the configuration and

29
00:01:29.910 --> 00:01:32.510
walk through the process
of creating a new mail tip.

30
00:01:34.970 --> 00:01:41.040
We are gonna start by getting
the organization config., and

31
00:01:41.040 --> 00:01:45.230
we're gonna select everything having to do
with mail tips or starting with mail tip.

32
00:01:46.470 --> 00:01:50.110
So, this is the default
settings in Exchange.

33
00:01:50.110 --> 00:01:52.220
AllTipsEnabled, true.

34
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:56.110
There's an ExternalRecipientsTip,
which is not enabled.

35
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:57.980
That's set to false.

36
00:01:57.980 --> 00:02:02.669
What that one does is warn you if you're
about to send to an external recipient.

37
00:02:03.890 --> 00:02:08.620
Today, I think that there's so many
emails going in and out of the internet.

38
00:02:08.620 --> 00:02:11.640
That if you were notified every
time you sent something externally,

39
00:02:11.640 --> 00:02:14.920
it would be a degraded user experience.

40
00:02:14.920 --> 00:02:16.410
But it's available for you.

41
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:21.184
Next, we're gonna do
a Set-OrganizationConfig.

42
00:02:23.310 --> 00:02:27.500
MailTipsExternalRecipientsTipsEnabled.

43
00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:28.060
It's a mouthful.

44
00:02:28.060 --> 00:02:29.680
We're gonna set that to true.

45
00:02:29.680 --> 00:02:34.460
And then we are going to
create a mail tip for

46
00:02:34.460 --> 00:02:39.520
a special distribution group,
our sales group.

47
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.450
And we can set this on a per
distribution group basis,

48
00:02:42.450 --> 00:02:47.600
a per mailbox basis, for right now
let's look at it at the sales one.

49
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:53.290
And our MailTip is gonna say,
to place an order immediately,

50
00:02:53.290 --> 00:02:56.814
call 949-555-1212.

51
00:03:01.420 --> 00:03:04.380
And now we have our first custom mail tip.

52
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:07.950
Let's give you a couple real
world use in this real quick.

53
00:03:07.950 --> 00:03:10.130
So I mean this is kind of a funny one,
right?

54
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:14.270
The sales team, hey instead of emailing
us, if you want an order, give us a call.

55
00:03:14.270 --> 00:03:15.400
You might set this up, though,

56
00:03:15.400 --> 00:03:18.590
on a support or
tech support type distribution group.

57
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:21.320
Saying hey,
if you need immediate assistance or

58
00:03:21.320 --> 00:03:27.080
if your computer is down, call our
extension instead, something like that.

59
00:03:27.080 --> 00:03:31.740
All right, so let's take a look at what it
looks like from the client perspective.

60
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:40.060
Let's get onto Client 1,
and this missed Day 4.

61
00:03:40.060 --> 00:03:41.560
And who we are on as?

62
00:03:41.560 --> 00:03:45.190
Looks like jack.jackson and
that will work.

63
00:03:45.190 --> 00:03:48.160
And what we're gonna do is
we're gonna send a new email,

64
00:03:48.160 --> 00:03:52.270
oops, we're gonna send it to sales.

65
00:03:53.520 --> 00:04:00.080
Have a couple of people that match that
term And we're gonna say testing, testing.

66
00:04:00.080 --> 00:04:01.880
So, I'm gonna make this smaller and

67
00:04:01.880 --> 00:04:04.300
zoom in to show you some
pertinent details here.

68
00:04:06.550 --> 00:04:08.120
So right up here at the top,

69
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:12.549
these two items are what
are referred to as mail tips.

70
00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:16.470
So I wanna focus on the bottom one.

71
00:04:16.470 --> 00:04:18.750
To place an order immediately call us,
right?

72
00:04:18.750 --> 00:04:20.610
That's the one we've just created.

73
00:04:20.610 --> 00:04:23.930
The other one is one of those
built-in mail tips I talked about.

74
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:28.260
This is when there's moderation
in place on a distribution group.

75
00:04:28.260 --> 00:04:34.230
So notice it says messages sent to it
might not Actually immediately appear,

76
00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:38.830
or might be rejected because the moderator
might say, hey, inappropriate.

77
00:04:38.830 --> 00:04:40.220
But that's two mail tips,

78
00:04:40.220 --> 00:04:43.950
you can display more than one on
a distribution group or on a mailbox.

79
00:04:43.950 --> 00:04:46.220
And they're fairly effective,

80
00:04:46.220 --> 00:04:49.400
you can use that red X next to them
to get rid of them if you want them.

81
00:04:50.470 --> 00:04:53.739
So, that in a nutshell, is what we're
talking about here with mail tips.

82
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:58.400
Now Brian another concept that we wanna
make sure that we address in terms of

83
00:04:58.400 --> 00:05:02.520
compliance is the idea of
message classification.

84
00:05:02.520 --> 00:05:05.820
Now why is something like this so
important to an organization?

85
00:05:06.880 --> 00:05:12.620
>> The message classification gives a user
the ability to classify an individual

86
00:05:12.620 --> 00:05:17.260
email message, with the idea that it would
>> Kinda say hey,

87
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:20.650
here's the intended audience or
the intended use for this message.

88
00:05:20.650 --> 00:05:23.030
So I'll give you an example.

89
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:25.480
Let's talk consulting company.

90
00:05:25.480 --> 00:05:31.330
And maybe they're a partner with
one of the big IT providers.

91
00:05:31.330 --> 00:05:36.050
And the idea is, is they get that partner
communication from the big IT provider.

92
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:40.350
>> The big IT provider can specify
certain documents as being partner only.

93
00:05:40.350 --> 00:05:42.290
They're not meant for the public.

94
00:05:42.290 --> 00:05:47.640
With message classification they can
mark those emails as partner only and

95
00:05:47.640 --> 00:05:51.780
what happens is if other users get those,
whether they're forwarded to them or

96
00:05:51.780 --> 00:05:54.810
whatever They'll see
that classification and

97
00:05:54.810 --> 00:05:57.640
know that's not something they
should put up on their blog or

98
00:05:57.640 --> 00:06:00.330
send it out to other people outside
the departmental organization.

99
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:03.738
So that's what we're talking about
with messaging classification.

100
00:06:03.738 --> 00:06:04.321
>.

101
00:06:04.321 --> 00:06:12.060
Now Brian sounds a lot like the idea
also of The rights management idea.

102
00:06:12.060 --> 00:06:16.120
So, if we have message classification, we
have that idea of the information rights

103
00:06:16.120 --> 00:06:19.420
management, when should I choose
to use one versus the other?

104
00:06:20.500 --> 00:06:21.390
>> Yeah, good question.

105
00:06:21.390 --> 00:06:28.550
So, message classification, think of it
as a less strict implementation, right?

106
00:06:28.550 --> 00:06:33.860
IRM is gonna be,
we're encrypting data That’s it, right.

107
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:39.610
Classification is an optional thing
that a user can decide to implement.

108
00:06:39.610 --> 00:06:42.160
And even if a message is classified

109
00:06:42.160 --> 00:06:45.040
it doesn't necessarily mean
there’s any actions placed on it.

110
00:06:45.040 --> 00:06:49.800
So, I might classify something as
partner only forward it over to Ronnie.

111
00:06:49.800 --> 00:06:52.090
And Ronnie can still send
it to whoever he wants.

112
00:06:52.090 --> 00:06:55.820
There's no protection, by default,
with just classification.

113
00:06:55.820 --> 00:07:02.470
One interesting aspect though, is you can
tie classification into mail flow rules.

114
00:07:02.470 --> 00:07:03.880
So, we talked about transport rules.

115
00:07:03.880 --> 00:07:07.210
We've showed some of that with DLP,
I think it was yesterday.

116
00:07:07.210 --> 00:07:12.530
And so we can actually make routing
decisions based on message classification.

117
00:07:12.530 --> 00:07:17.700
So say if I see message
classified is internal only

118
00:07:17.700 --> 00:07:21.370
heading to an external recipient I
can block that with a mail flow rule.

119
00:07:21.370 --> 00:07:25.740
So there are some things that you can put
in place from a security perspective but

120
00:07:25.740 --> 00:07:29.330
it's still not the same as
full message encryption.

121
00:07:29.330 --> 00:07:30.940
All right.
So how do we get started with

122
00:07:30.940 --> 00:07:34.010
trying to classify these messages?

123
00:07:34.010 --> 00:07:37.070
>> So first step, we need to
create an actual classification.

124
00:07:37.070 --> 00:07:39.080
So let's drop down to the computer and
take a look at that.

125
00:07:41.430 --> 00:07:46.205
So we're on Mailbox server number one.

126
00:07:46.205 --> 00:07:49.925
New-MessageClassification, there we go.

127
00:07:49.925 --> 00:07:56.771
Name, we're gonna call
this one "Partners"-

128
00:07:56.771 --> 00:08:02.322
DisplayName "Channel Partners Only.

129
00:08:02.322 --> 00:08:05.700
And then we're gonna SenderDescription.

130
00:08:05.700 --> 00:08:09.792
Material approved for

131
00:08:09.792 --> 00:08:13.456
channel partners.

132
00:08:13.456 --> 00:08:16.371
RecipientDescription.

133
00:08:16.371 --> 00:08:22.220
Message is restricted to
the partner community.

134
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:28.500
Okay, so, now,
we have a message classification.

135
00:08:28.500 --> 00:08:32.230
In general, you'll have a whole bunch of
these based on your organization's needs.

136
00:08:33.280 --> 00:08:38.176
Next, we are gonna go off to
our client computer, client1.

137
00:08:38.176 --> 00:08:42.902
Let me close our previous test here.

138
00:08:42.902 --> 00:08:48.626
And I am going to go up to OWA.

139
00:08:48.626 --> 00:08:56.088
There we go on mailbox
server one we will sign in,

140
00:08:56.088 --> 00:09:03.190
and we are going to create
a new email message.

141
00:09:04.190 --> 00:09:07.580
And let me scroll over
pretty big resolution here.

142
00:09:08.690 --> 00:09:12.110
Let's send this over to Ronnie,
he's still on our directory?

143
00:09:14.520 --> 00:09:16.572
There he is, subject.

144
00:09:16.572 --> 00:09:22.370
Okay, so this is my email message,
and this particular

145
00:09:22.370 --> 00:09:25.870
one I think should be restricted to
partners with that new classification.

146
00:09:25.870 --> 00:09:27.760
We have this little ellipsis up here.

147
00:09:28.930 --> 00:09:29.810
We're gonna click that.

148
00:09:30.840 --> 00:09:33.150
We're gonna go down to Set permissions.

149
00:09:33.150 --> 00:09:37.300
And you're gonna see
Channel Partners Only right here.

150
00:09:37.300 --> 00:09:39.260
Now, there's an interesting
component here,

151
00:09:39.260 --> 00:09:43.960
because you're also seeing some
other stuff like Do Not Forward.

152
00:09:43.960 --> 00:09:46.220
Those actually come from IRM.

153
00:09:46.220 --> 00:09:51.570
So, earlier, Ronnie was asking about
the tie in IRM and message classification.

154
00:09:51.570 --> 00:09:54.016
They're both sort of security focused,

155
00:09:54.016 --> 00:09:58.760
and in OWA, they combine them together for
the end user.

156
00:09:58.760 --> 00:10:00.200
So, just be aware of that.

157
00:10:00.200 --> 00:10:04.623
So, we're going to click channel partners
only, and now you can see that we've got

158
00:10:04.623 --> 00:10:08.720
this little status message, material,
or proof of channel partners.

159
00:10:08.720 --> 00:10:11.740
That was the message that we
put in when we created it.

160
00:10:13.070 --> 00:10:15.450
We will go ahead and
send that over to Ronnie.

161
00:10:15.450 --> 00:10:19.880
And there you have it, Ronnie will
also see that classification in OWA.

162
00:10:19.880 --> 00:10:23.670
And he can choose to ignore it or
follow it.

163
00:10:23.670 --> 00:10:28.580
And then what happens, is based on whether
we have any other transport rules.

164
00:10:28.580 --> 00:10:31.090
One more key point, we are in OWA,

165
00:10:31.090 --> 00:10:34.690
you might be wondering why, why aren't
we in Outlook and seeing it there.

166
00:10:34.690 --> 00:10:39.600
Well, that's, because, Outlook by default
doesn't work with message classification.

167
00:10:39.600 --> 00:10:44.120
Instead, you need to distribute these
XML file usually through like group

168
00:10:44.120 --> 00:10:47.720
policy to Outlook in order for
it to work with classification.

169
00:10:47.720 --> 00:10:50.950
So, that's something to definitely
be aware of for the exam.

170
00:10:52.120 --> 00:10:56.250
>> All right, now, Brian since you
mentioned the idea of transport rules

171
00:10:56.250 --> 00:10:57.980
in dealing with compliance.

172
00:10:57.980 --> 00:11:01.270
What are some of the issues that we
definitely need to consider in terms of

173
00:11:01.270 --> 00:11:04.530
those transport rules, and the issues
of compliance that we're talking about?

174
00:11:05.750 --> 00:11:11.260
So, transport rules they're
very powerful we've

175
00:11:11.260 --> 00:11:15.510
seen how they can already do other stuff,
I think, we did, quite a bit yesterday.

176
00:11:15.510 --> 00:11:18.080
Today we're gonna see a couple more uses.

177
00:11:18.080 --> 00:11:21.240
I wanna show you one particularly
right now at the computer, so

178
00:11:21.240 --> 00:11:23.000
let's drop down to that.

179
00:11:23.000 --> 00:11:26.785
We're gonna go back to
Mailbox server number one.

180
00:11:30.628 --> 00:11:32.370
Let me clear this stuff out.

181
00:11:33.470 --> 00:11:35.420
So, you can do a whole
bunch with transport rules.

182
00:11:35.420 --> 00:11:39.010

a whole bunch of say like new mailboxes.

00:26:16.175 --> 00:26:18.205
And you didn't care to audit that data,

411
00:26:18.205 --> 00:26:21.560
you could throw the new-mailboxcmdlet
in and exclude it.

412
00:26:21.560 --> 00:26:24.730
That helps clean up the amount
of data in the AdminAuditLog.

413
00:26:24.730 --> 00:26:28.778
And then finally, the LogAgeLimit,
that's the default, it's set to 90 days.

414
00:26:28.778 --> 00:26:33.380
So what that means is,
any searches we perform go back 90 days,

415
00:26:33.380 --> 00:26:38.010
if you need to go back further,
you can adjust that there.

416
00:26:38.010 --> 00:26:41.050
So let's take a look real quick
at how you can make an adjustment

417
00:26:41.050 --> 00:26:43.220
to your AdminAuditLogConfig.

418
00:26:43.220 --> 00:26:47.179
It's fairly straight forward,
Set-AdminAuditLogConfig,

419
00:26:47.179 --> 00:26:51.513
then you just specify one of
the properties like we're looking here.

420
00:26:51.513 --> 00:26:58.090
We're gonna do
an AdminAuditLogExcludedCmdlets.

421
00:26:58.090 --> 00:27:06.040
And let's do New-Mailbox, Could take
up to 60 minutes to take effect.

422
00:27:06.040 --> 00:27:11.424
Now we're gonna go back, and
when we get the configuration this time,

423
00:27:11.424 --> 00:27:14.397
you can see New-Mailbox is excluded.

424
00:27:14.397 --> 00:27:17.482
So fairly basic high level stuff here.

425
00:27:17.482 --> 00:27:20.218
That's how you look at what
you're configuration is,

426
00:27:20.218 --> 00:27:23.680
how you can set some of
those basic properties too.

427
00:27:23.680 --> 00:27:28.351
>> Now earlier Brian,
you also showed us the ability to take

428
00:27:28.351 --> 00:27:33.425
a look at the logs for the managed,
the mailbox owner as well.

429
00:27:33.425 --> 00:27:36.400
Is there another command
that's different for us?

430
00:27:36.400 --> 00:27:39.230
We take a look at the idea,
the administrative side?

431
00:27:39.230 --> 00:27:42.553
>> Yes, so similar to the mailbox side,
we've got a search cmdlet and

432
00:27:42.553 --> 00:27:45.060
it will pull down tons of information.

433
00:27:45.060 --> 00:27:46.510
It's slightly different and

434
00:27:46.510 --> 00:27:49.320
the information that comes back is of
course a little bit different too.

435
00:27:49.320 --> 00:27:52.910
Let's head back to the PowerShell
prompt and take a look.

436
00:27:52.910 --> 00:27:56.152
So we're still at mailbox
server number one,

437
00:27:56.152 --> 00:27:59.570
we are gonna
Search-AdminAuditLog this time.

438
00:28:01.010 --> 00:28:02.720
And I'm gonna go ahead and

439
00:28:02.720 --> 00:28:08.510
let this thing run just to show you how
extensive the information that comes back.

440
00:28:09.940 --> 00:28:12.790
You can see it just keep going and
going and going.

441
00:28:12.790 --> 00:28:14.860
And there's all the work that
we've actually done this week.

442
00:28:15.970 --> 00:28:17.220
Okay, so there we have it.

443
00:28:17.220 --> 00:28:19.980
Obviously too much, it's totally unusable.

444
00:28:19.980 --> 00:28:22.210
Let's work down through some filters and

445
00:28:22.210 --> 00:28:24.490
see if we can make it
a little more useful.

446
00:28:24.490 --> 00:28:29.464
So we are gonna specify
where the Caller -eq

447
00:28:29.464 --> 00:28:33.680
bsvidergol@hugelab.net.

448
00:28:33.680 --> 00:28:37.730
You'll notice this is not my primary admin
account, this is the secondary admin

449
00:28:37.730 --> 00:28:42.060
account that hasn't had as much activity,
just pointing that out.

450
00:28:42.060 --> 00:28:46.340
So if I were to do just that,
you can see it's already finished up.

451
00:28:46.340 --> 00:28:48.820
But it's still quite a bit of data, so

452
00:28:48.820 --> 00:28:51.930
what we are gonna do is
drive down even further.

453
00:28:51.930 --> 00:28:55.729
We're gonna form a list and

454
00:28:55.729 --> 00:29:02.007
we are gonna just grab caller,CmdletName,

455
00:29:02.007 --> 00:29:06.971
RunDate, and CmdletParameters.

456
00:29:10.366 --> 00:29:11.675
Let that run.

457
00:29:11.675 --> 00:29:16.655
And so scrolling back up we
probably have maybe 20 or

458
00:29:16.655 --> 00:29:20.125
so cmdlets that he's run,
and it's fairly useable.

459
00:29:20.125 --> 00:29:23.470
You can see we ran the add
mailbox permission.

460
00:29:23.470 --> 00:29:28.450
And the parameters I specified
are AccessRight, AutoMapping,

461
00:29:28.450 --> 00:29:29.690
User and Identity.

462
00:29:29.690 --> 00:29:31.860
You might remember,
we talked about AutoMapping.

463
00:29:31.860 --> 00:29:36.610
So it sounds like we added somebody
to full access on a mailbox and

464
00:29:36.610 --> 00:29:39.270
we probably disabled AutoMapping.

465
00:29:39.270 --> 00:29:41.420
So just looking at the AdminAutoLog,

466
00:29:41.420 --> 00:29:43.620
we can sort of interpret
all of that stuff, right?

467
00:29:43.620 --> 00:29:49.020
There's also additional information on
which objects were actually modified,

468
00:29:49.020 --> 00:29:51.290
I didn't pull back everything in this one.

469
00:29:51.290 --> 00:29:56.540
Here we've got New-Mailbox, which we're
no longer capturing in our AdminAutoLogs,

470
00:29:56.540 --> 00:29:58.510
but this is historical data.

471
00:29:58.510 --> 00:30:01.890
And you can again see the parameters,
and you can see the RunDate.

472
00:30:01.890 --> 00:30:05.210
So imagine that you've got
a whole team of administrators,

473
00:30:05.210 --> 00:30:08.580
somebody makes a change to
the organizational configuration.

474
00:30:08.580 --> 00:30:11.100
And you've gotta figure out,
when did it happen and

475
00:30:11.100 --> 00:30:14.870
who did it and
was there a mistake in the command?

476
00:30:14.870 --> 00:30:16.920
Well you can find out by
looking at the parameters and

477
00:30:16.920 --> 00:30:18.440
looking at all these details.

478
00:30:18.440 --> 00:30:19.420
Very, very useful.

479
00:30:20.960 --> 00:30:23.170
>> All right Brian,
well that's a lot of information.

480
00:30:23.170 --> 00:30:26.490
When we take a look at both
compliance as well as auditing.

481
00:30:26.490 --> 00:30:30.440
Remember that in this episode we saw quite
a bit on how to set up and make sure that

482
00:30:30.440 --> 00:30:34.750
everything is running according to the way
that we're set up for a compliance.

483
00:30:34.750 --> 00:30:38.920
So make sure you go back and
you review those bigger topics as well.

484
00:30:38.920 --> 00:30:42.605
Brian also emphasized in each of those
sections in compliance compare them with

485
00:30:42.605 --> 00:30:44.151
other tools that sound similar.

486
00:30:44.151 --> 00:30:48.239
So that we know exactly which tool
we would use in that situation for

487
00:30:48.239 --> 00:30:50.040
compliance as well.

488
00:30:50.040 --> 00:30:54.760
And also in auditing, Ryan showed us this
ability of course to go back through and

489
00:30:54.760 --> 00:30:58.570
not only monitor the mail
box owner's actions.

490
00:30:58.570 --> 00:31:02.130
But also of course
the administrative actions for

491
00:31:02.130 --> 00:31:05.470
the Exchange administrator as well and
everything that they do.

492
00:31:05.470 --> 00:31:08.890
And all this is combining together
to help make sure that we're

493
00:31:08.890 --> 00:31:12.270
getting things the way they need to
be according to compliance measures.

494
00:31:12.270 --> 00:31:13.990
And that were actually able to go back and

495
00:31:13.990 --> 00:31:16.730
verify it through the logs
that are actually there too.

496
00:31:16.730 --> 00:31:18.780
So there's a lot of that information.

497
00:31:18.780 --> 00:31:22.790
Now Brian,
as we again get ready for the exam.

498
00:31:22.790 --> 00:31:26.350
Any final words on this particular
last two topics that we wantna

499
00:31:26.350 --> 00:31:30.720
make sure that we get into for
the watchers that are out there.

500
00:31:30.720 --> 00:31:32.740
>> Well hopefully you guys
aren't tired of hearing this.

501
00:31:32.740 --> 00:31:37.980
But I think my recommendation here is
flip this stuff on in your environment.

502
00:31:37.980 --> 00:31:39.970
Let it run for a few days,
capture some data,

503
00:31:39.970 --> 00:31:44.500
and then run back through it,
get your hands on it, run these commands.

504
00:31:44.500 --> 00:31:47.938
And that's one of the best ways that
you're gonna remember this stuff as you

505
00:31:47.938 --> 00:31:48.970
prepare for the exam.

506
00:31:48.970 --> 00:31:51.128
>> All right, well Brian,
thank you again for

507
00:31:51.128 --> 00:31:53.355
helping us in all of
these different topics.

508
00:31:53.355 --> 00:31:56.850
It would've been a lot more difficult
without you here helping us.

509
00:31:56.850 --> 00:31:59.000
And thank you also for watching.

510
00:31:59.000 --> 00:32:02.090
But that's a great place for
us to sign off for this episode.

511
00:32:02.090 --> 00:32:04.856
For ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

512
00:32:04.856 --> 00:32:05.958
>> And I'm Brian Svidergol.

513
00:32:05.958 --> 00:32:10.374
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Exchange 2016 shows.

514
00:32:10.374 --> 00:32:16.302
[MUSIC]

515
00:32:16.302 --> 00:32:19.551
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

topics.title: Plan, deploy, and manage compliance, archiving, eDiscovery, and auditing

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie help us to get started with an hybrid coexistence with Exchange Online.  They briefly mention the prerequisites for making it work and then run through the Hybrid Configuration Wizard to help show the setup.  The guys also emphasize the use of OAuth for authentication in hybrid deployments and the technologies dependent on it.  Brian describes the certificate and firewall issues that may also cause issues with the hybrid deployment.  They end the episode by troubleshooting transport and client access issues with Exchange online and Directory Synchronization.
episodes.title: Coexistence with Office 365
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.346
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.346 --> 00:00:06.378
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.378 --> 00:00:08.329
>> [MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.329 --> 00:00:12.559
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.559 --> 00:00:16.190
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.190 --> 00:00:21.630
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today we're
taking a look at planning, deploying and

7
00:00:21.630 --> 00:00:27.140
troubleshooting coexistence with
Office 365 Exchange Online,

8
00:00:27.140 --> 00:00:30.110
that's quite a mouthful
that we chosen to do here.

9
00:00:30.110 --> 00:00:34.935
And here with us is our Exchange expert,
Mr Brian Svidergol.

10
00:00:34.935 --> 00:00:38.660
Brian help us out here when we start
talking about this idea of coexistence

11
00:00:38.660 --> 00:00:44.130
with Exchange Online and the Office 365
portion, what do we really mean by that?

12
00:00:44.130 --> 00:00:45.669
And where are we gonna
beginning this topic?

13
00:00:46.680 --> 00:00:47.320
>> Yeah, thanks, Ronnie.

14
00:00:47.320 --> 00:00:50.110
So, here's situation with coexistence.

15
00:00:50.110 --> 00:00:53.891
Coexistence is the idea that
you have something on premises,

16
00:00:53.891 --> 00:00:58.836
like your exchange environment, and
that you're gonna coexist it with another

17
00:00:58.836 --> 00:01:02.122
environment such as
Office365 Exchange Online.

18
00:01:02.122 --> 00:01:03.828
That's coexistence.

19
00:01:03.828 --> 00:01:07.470
And coexistence is a temporary state for

20
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:09.810
some organizations that are going
to move fully to the cloud.

21
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:13.230
And for other organizations it
could be a permanent thing.

22
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:17.460
We're going to start off today by
looking at the hybrid configuration.

23
00:01:18.800 --> 00:01:21.570
And I want to start off
looking at the diagram, and

24
00:01:21.570 --> 00:01:22.799
walk through some of the components.

25
00:01:23.910 --> 00:01:28.808
So, here is our diagram for
our hybrid configuration.

26
00:01:28.808 --> 00:01:33.250
On the left-hand-side is our on
premises implementation, and

27
00:01:33.250 --> 00:01:35.810
I just want to point
out a couple of things.

28
00:01:35.810 --> 00:01:38.360
Let's start with the prerequisites for
that hybrid.

29
00:01:38.360 --> 00:01:40.900
First of all,
on the mailbox server side down here,

30
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:42.990
we have to have a supported version.

31
00:01:42.990 --> 00:01:48.340
That's the Exchange 2010 SP3, or newer.

32
00:01:48.340 --> 00:01:54.070
Exchange 2013 with the current cumulative
update, or the previous cumulative update,

33
00:01:54.070 --> 00:01:59.070
or of course 2016 current
cumulative update, or previous.

34
00:01:59.070 --> 00:02:03.390
The other thing we need is
an Office 365 subscription.

35
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:07.543
And the subscription that has
Exchange online is part of that.

36
00:02:07.543 --> 00:02:10.120
A couple of other pieces
I wanna point out.

37
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:12.330
The domain name that we use here for

38
00:02:12.330 --> 00:02:17.460
active directory is commonly going to
be used out here in the cloud as well.

39
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:21.370
And, so one of the things that we need to
do is we need to get that domain name.

40
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:25.640
Out here in Office 365, there's a couple
of prerequisites when you add it.

41
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:28.380
You have to validate and
prove that you own the domain.

42
00:02:28.380 --> 00:02:30.800
And that's normally
done with a DNS record.

43
00:02:32.070 --> 00:02:36.150
And then you run through a hybrid
configuration wizard, and

44
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:38.030
we're gonna run through that next.

45
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:42.754
And eventually, we're gonna synchronize
our internal identities to act as your

46
00:02:42.754 --> 00:02:43.923
active directory.

47
00:02:43.923 --> 00:02:48.315
In this particular segment, we're actually
going to walk through the trouble shooting

48
00:02:48.315 --> 00:02:51.593
process of some of that, but
that requires an on premises server,

49
00:02:51.593 --> 00:02:55.270
it requires the federation trust,
and it requires this scene.

50
00:02:55.270 --> 00:02:58.520
There's a bunch of options tied
to some of these components.

51
00:02:58.520 --> 00:03:02.520
We're going to be walking through them as
we move further along in this segment.

52
00:03:02.520 --> 00:03:03.290
>> All right, now, Brian,

53
00:03:03.290 --> 00:03:06.920
you had mentioned this idea of
hybrid configuration wizard.

54
00:03:06.920 --> 00:03:11.840
What are some of the limitations that we
to be aware of when we start talking about

55
00:03:11.840 --> 00:03:15.950
we're gonna make this thing happen for
this hybrid coexistence?

56
00:03:16.990 --> 00:03:21.860
>> Yeah, the hybrid configuration
wizard is the simplified way

57
00:03:21.860 --> 00:03:25.323
to take your on premises organization, and

58
00:03:25.323 --> 00:03:30.206
configure it to be part of
Office 365 Hybrid Environment.

59
00:03:30.206 --> 00:03:32.874
And I think,
one of the easiest ways to describe it and

60
00:03:32.874 --> 00:03:36.380
show it to you is just to walk
through the actual configuration.

61
00:03:36.380 --> 00:03:37.780
So, we're going to take.

62
00:03:37.780 --> 00:03:42.299
The Huge Lab on-premises Exchange
environment, and we're gonna run through

63
00:03:42.299 --> 00:03:46.492
the Hybrid Configuration Wizard to
connect it up with our Office 365.

64
00:03:46.492 --> 00:03:49.610
All right, so
here we are on mailbox server number one.

65
00:03:49.610 --> 00:03:53.600
We're gonna walk through
the Hybrid Configuration Wizard.

66
00:03:53.600 --> 00:03:56.830
We are in the Exchange
admin center on MBX one.

67
00:03:56.830 --> 00:04:01.900
And we have navigated over here, now,
we can't see with this resolution, but

68
00:04:01.900 --> 00:04:05.260
we're in the hybrid section, which would
normally be displayed in the left pane.

69
00:04:05.260 --> 00:04:07.500
We are going to go ahead and
click configure.

70
00:04:09.560 --> 00:04:12.274
We need to sign into Office 365.

71
00:04:12.274 --> 00:04:14.226
This is gonna bring up a prompt.

72
00:04:26.509 --> 00:04:31.470
And once we sign in, it brings us right
back to the configuration component.

73
00:04:31.470 --> 00:04:33.236
We click configure again,

74
00:04:43.634 --> 00:04:49.960
We're gonna click here, and
it's gonna download the application.

75
00:04:49.960 --> 00:04:51.406
We're gonna click Install.

76
00:04:57.960 --> 00:04:58.721
Run.

77
00:05:02.438 --> 00:05:07.700
And here is the official office 365
hybrid configuration tool, get started.

78
00:05:07.700 --> 00:05:09.319
We are gonna get click next.

79
00:05:11.090 --> 00:05:14.720
And here it detects the optimal
Exchange server to use.

80
00:05:14.720 --> 00:05:16.550
Notice it grabs the version information.

81
00:05:16.550 --> 00:05:20.330
Earlier we talked about some of
the prerequisites being on the cumulative

82
00:05:20.330 --> 00:05:21.750
update, or the previous one.

83
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:24.312
We're going to go ahead and click next.

84
00:05:26.725 --> 00:05:28.845
And then we can use our
current credentials for

85
00:05:28.845 --> 00:05:31.090
the on-premises exchange environment.

86
00:05:31.090 --> 00:05:34.617
We are logged in as an exchange admin,
so we are good here.

87
00:05:38.238 --> 00:05:42.042
I'm gonna also reauthenticate here.

88
00:05:53.985 --> 00:05:58.521
Okay, so, now, both environments
are picked up, we're gonna click Next, and

89
00:05:58.521 --> 00:06:02.225
this is gonna gather configuration
information from both sides,

90
00:06:11.502 --> 00:06:13.240
This is usually fairly quick.

91
00:06:15.730 --> 00:06:17.200
There it goes.

92
00:06:17.200 --> 00:06:18.240
And both succeeded.

93
00:06:18.240 --> 00:06:19.915
That's what we wanna see.

94
00:06:19.915 --> 00:06:21.270
We're gonna click Next.

95
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:24.960
And we have two options, minimal or full.

96
00:06:24.960 --> 00:06:29.330
Minimal is the basic
foundation of Hybrid for us,

97
00:06:29.330 --> 00:06:32.155
that's what we gonna walk through
especially for the demonstration purposes.

98
00:06:32.155 --> 00:06:36.608
Full includes all of the features that
a Hybrid gives you, some of the advanced

99
00:06:36.608 --> 00:06:41.282
eDiscovery feature we're actually gonna
cover a few of those a little bit later.

100
00:06:45.594 --> 00:06:47.740
And, now, we're gonna click update.

101
00:06:49.390 --> 00:06:53.372
So, these updates the configuration on
both sides to be in hybrid mode, and

102
00:06:53.372 --> 00:06:56.809
if it completes successfully
then officially we're in hybrid.

103
00:06:56.809 --> 00:07:00.482
And if you guys remember, we've covered
some features over the last couple of days

104
00:07:00.482 --> 00:07:08.413
that required us to be in hybrid mode
>> Now,

105
00:07:08.413 --> 00:07:12.584
Brian, while we're actually taking a look
at this idea that configuration as

106
00:07:12.584 --> 00:07:15.300
we start to take a look
at hybrid mode here.

107
00:07:15.300 --> 00:07:19.430
Walking through the actual hybrid
configuration wizard seems fairly easy as

108
00:07:19.430 --> 00:07:23.090
long as you actually realize,
which particular mode that we need, right?

109
00:07:23.090 --> 00:07:25.090
Whether we need the minimal,
or the full install.

110
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:27.490
But that's something we should we
decide during our planning, right?

111
00:07:28.510 --> 00:07:31.350
>> Yeah, exactly,
that's another planning consideration.

112
00:07:31.350 --> 00:07:32.900
For a lot of environments,

113
00:07:32.900 --> 00:07:38.130
you're gonna go with the full hybrid
depending on what you're planning to do.

114
00:07:38.130 --> 00:07:40.421
For those that are gonna move
to the cloud eventually, or

115
00:07:40.421 --> 00:07:42.624
wanna have full services in
the cloud like mail boxes.

116
00:07:42.624 --> 00:07:44.233
Then you want to go with the full,

117
00:07:44.233 --> 00:07:48.377
if you're thinking about something like
archive only, or just doing some testing,

118
00:07:48.377 --> 00:07:52.550
or you're in the development environment,
you may not need it.

119
00:07:52.550 --> 00:07:54.766
>> All right, Brian,
it looks like it's actually finished now,

120
00:07:54.766 --> 00:07:55.677
so what's our next step?

121
00:07:55.677 --> 00:07:59.403
>> So, we're totally done
with this topic and, I think,

122

So remember, we did the Outlook test and

354
00:21:42.950 --> 00:21:47.470
that gives us the MAPI over HTTP test,
which is one way to connect up Outlook.

355
00:21:47.470 --> 00:21:52.454
And the other one is the Outlook Anywhere,
which is RPC over HTTP,

356
00:21:52.454 --> 00:21:54.241
which this also tests.

357
00:21:57.150 --> 00:22:00.420
And here is our testing RPC over HTTP.

358
00:22:00.420 --> 00:22:02.280
Everything going to Office 365.

359
00:22:02.280 --> 00:22:05.040
So by all intents and
purposes, for all intents and

360
00:22:05.040 --> 00:22:10.070
purposes, the test was successful,
everybody's happy, this thing's working.

361
00:22:10.070 --> 00:22:13.090
But this tool is where
you want to start and

362
00:22:13.090 --> 00:22:15.690
test all your connectivity
from the client pieces.

363
00:22:17.100 --> 00:22:21.050
>> All right, Brian, we have one more
topic to cover in this particular episode,

364
00:22:21.050 --> 00:22:24.250
which is, of course,
Directory Synchronization.

365
00:22:24.250 --> 00:22:27.390
And we might need to begin
with troubleshooting that,

366
00:22:27.390 --> 00:22:28.500
there's issues that go on.

367
00:22:28.500 --> 00:22:30.770
Synchronizing might be
one of the big ones.

368
00:22:30.770 --> 00:22:32.600
So Brian, where do we begin?

369
00:22:32.600 --> 00:22:35.350
>> Alright so where do we begin
with Directory Synchronization?

370
00:22:35.350 --> 00:22:40.200
Well its an interesting topic, you know
there's not a lot of coverage on the exam

371
00:22:40.200 --> 00:22:44.040
but there is a dedicated section for
troubleshooting it.

372
00:22:44.040 --> 00:22:48.320
And makes it tough because you don't
see the initial set up process and

373
00:22:48.320 --> 00:22:52.040
some of the initial configuration,
it's just straight into troubleshooting.

374
00:22:52.040 --> 00:22:55.210
We're gonna walk through some
of those troubleshooting steps.

375
00:22:55.210 --> 00:22:58.720
And first, let me give you
just a high level overview of

376
00:22:58.720 --> 00:23:01.860
what Directory Synchronization
actually entails.

377
00:23:01.860 --> 00:23:06.180
It's Azure Active Directory Connect,
that's a free download from Microsoft.

378
00:23:06.180 --> 00:23:09.440
You install it on a tool, it doesn't
need to be a domain controller or

379
00:23:09.440 --> 00:23:10.710
an Exchange server.

380
00:23:10.710 --> 00:23:14.420
Typically it's a utility
server of some sort and

381
00:23:14.420 --> 00:23:18.620
that tool takes your on-premises
Active Directory information,

382
00:23:18.620 --> 00:23:21.780
synchronizes it and
pushes it up to Azure Active Directory.

383
00:23:21.780 --> 00:23:27.150
You need to have Global Administrative
Access up in Office 365 and

384
00:23:27.150 --> 00:23:32.880
you also need an administrative account
on-premises for that initial installation.

385
00:23:32.880 --> 00:23:37.890
And once you have the thing configured
it will sync every 30 minutes up

386
00:23:37.890 --> 00:23:41.750
to Azure Active Directory and
it's based on your configuration.

387
00:23:41.750 --> 00:23:45.540
It can be all users and devices,
it can be some users and

388
00:23:45.540 --> 00:23:50.236
devices, it can be based on a group or
just some specified OUs.

389
00:23:50.236 --> 00:23:54.299
So without further ado, that's the intro,
let's look at the computer and

390
00:23:54.299 --> 00:23:56.403
take a walk through some of this stuff.

391
00:23:56.403 --> 00:24:00.525
So we are on Util1,
that's our Utility server, and

392
00:24:00.525 --> 00:24:03.187
it is our Azure AD Connect Server.

393
00:24:03.187 --> 00:24:08.211
The first thing I wanna do is I'm gonna
launch the Azure AD connect tool.

394
00:24:08.211 --> 00:24:10.639
And we're gonna look at the configuration.

395
00:24:10.639 --> 00:24:14.359
I think, this is helpful especially for
those that haven't set this up or

396
00:24:14.359 --> 00:24:15.870
seen it before.

397
00:24:15.870 --> 00:24:18.790
One of the things I wanna point out
right from the beginning is that,

398
00:24:18.790 --> 00:24:22.420
when I launch this
synchronization is disabled.

399
00:24:22.420 --> 00:24:24.560
So once I'm done in here,
I wanna close it back out so

400
00:24:24.560 --> 00:24:26.880
synchronization is enabled again.

401
00:24:26.880 --> 00:24:28.537
We're gonna click Configure and

402
00:24:28.537 --> 00:24:31.210
we're gonna click View
the current configuration.

403
00:24:34.292 --> 00:24:38.851
So, here's our high-level configuration,
you can see that we're

404
00:24:38.851 --> 00:24:43.496
synchronizing the hugelab.net domain and
it's going up to Azure AD.

405
00:24:43.496 --> 00:24:47.984
And, this is the admin account
that I used for the set up.

406
00:24:47.984 --> 00:24:50.849
And then we have some of our
synchronization settings.

407
00:24:50.849 --> 00:24:55.357
Some of these are tied to your
synchronization configuration.

408
00:24:55.357 --> 00:24:58.816
I wanna point out a couple, I wanna make
this a little smaller so I can zoom in and

409
00:24:58.816 --> 00:25:05.234
highlight a couple of things Okay,
so when we look at stuff

410
00:25:05.234 --> 00:25:10.740
like DEVICE WRITEBACK, these are optional
features of the directory synchronization.

411
00:25:10.740 --> 00:25:12.640
You can enable them or you don't have to.

412
00:25:12.640 --> 00:25:16.070
All of these optional features
are disabled by default.

413
00:25:16.070 --> 00:25:19.660
The one that we do have
enabled required for

414
00:25:19.660 --> 00:25:23.840
the hybrid deployment Is this one,
EXCHANGE HYBRID DEPLOYMENT.

415
00:25:23.840 --> 00:25:28.293
So, during the installation and
the configuration, I specifically selected

416
00:25:28.293 --> 00:25:32.022
that one knowing that I wanted to
do a Hybrid with Exchange Online.

417
00:25:32.022 --> 00:25:37.070
And then this last one I wanna show
you too, PASSWORD SYNCHRONIZATION.

418
00:25:37.070 --> 00:25:41.410
So, not only are we
synching to Office 365 and

419
00:25:41.410 --> 00:25:45.650
Azure AD but, we're also authenticating
and we have a couple of options there.

420
00:25:45.650 --> 00:25:48.140
One, we can do password synchronization,

421
00:25:48.140 --> 00:25:50.680
which is what this lab
environment is configured for.

422
00:25:50.680 --> 00:25:55.360
What that means is,
part of the sink, it takes a secured

423
00:25:55.360 --> 00:25:59.180
hash of your password hash,
syncs it up to Azure AD.

424
00:25:59.180 --> 00:26:03.200
So when I go up to Azure AD,
I can log on with my

425
00:26:03.200 --> 00:26:07.040
huge lab credentials because
they've been synchronized up there.

426
00:26:07.040 --> 00:26:09.460
But, it's still two separate accounts.

427
00:26:09.460 --> 00:26:11.690
Earlier, we talked about ADFS and

428
00:26:11.690 --> 00:26:15.160
there were other solutions too
that you could use instead.

429
00:26:15.160 --> 00:26:19.120
But, the big picture here is that
we got password synchronization,

430
00:26:19.120 --> 00:26:21.200
we've got the Hybrid configuration.

431
00:26:21.200 --> 00:26:25.120
And now, I wanna show you a little bit
more than just that initial configuration.

432
00:26:25.120 --> 00:26:26.015
Let's drop back to the computer.

433
00:26:28.484 --> 00:26:31.262
So, we're gonna Exit out out of here and

434
00:26:31.262 --> 00:26:36.480
I wanna show you when you have this
installed, what ends up happening?

435
00:26:36.480 --> 00:26:42.030
You end up with a single service and
it's called Microsoft Azure AD Sync.

436
00:26:42.030 --> 00:26:44.000
It's Running, it's set to Automatic.

437
00:26:44.000 --> 00:26:48.680
And, you can see that it's logging
on as a service account and

438
00:26:48.680 --> 00:26:51.250
that service account actually
lives in Azure Active Directory.

439
00:26:52.300 --> 00:26:56.190
So, part of your trouble shooting,
is the service running?

440
00:26:56.190 --> 00:26:58.696
If it is,
you always can optionally stop it and

441
00:26:58.696 --> 00:27:01.149
start it as you would
any other application.

442
00:27:01.149 --> 00:27:03.232
Okay, that's one component.

443
00:27:03.232 --> 00:27:08.730
Now I wanna show you another tool which
is the Synchronization Service Manager.

444
00:27:10.030 --> 00:27:13.770
This is the tool that keeps track of
all your syncs, all your activities,

445
00:27:13.770 --> 00:27:16.630
what's going on and logs the changes,

446
00:27:16.630 --> 00:27:21.030
the adds,
all the items that happen during a sync.

447
00:27:21.030 --> 00:27:24.800
So I'm gonna scroll down
here to our initial sync,

448
00:27:24.800 --> 00:27:26.780
where we have a little bit of data.

449
00:27:26.780 --> 00:27:30.950
Okay, so this is a little bit earlier,
we can see that this is a full import.

450
00:27:30.950 --> 00:27:33.980
I'm gonna zoom in a little bit here.

451
00:27:33.980 --> 00:27:39.670
So, right here it tells you whether it's
a full import or a Full Synchronization.

452
00:27:39.670 --> 00:27:43.520
That's the initial all these right
here are the initial set up and

453
00:27:43.520 --> 00:27:45.310
first run, right?

454
00:27:45.310 --> 00:27:48.535
After that, we do a bunch of
delta imports and delta syncs.

455
00:27:48.535 --> 00:27:53.925
These are basically when changes happen,
okay?

456
00:27:53.925 --> 00:27:55.496
Wanna show you a little bit more here.

457
00:27:55.496 --> 00:28:00.549
You can click on all this underlined blue
stuff and take a look at what happened.

458
00:28:00.549 --> 00:28:06.302
So let's click here and here are the total
object retrieved from the directory.

459
00:28:08.062 --> 00:28:09.191
There's quite a bit of stuff.

460
00:28:09.191 --> 00:28:11.550
We have a bunch of users in here.

461
00:28:11.550 --> 00:28:15.680
So this configuration actually said,
grab everything and sync it up.

462
00:28:15.680 --> 00:28:18.370
That way, whoever I want to
put up there with a mailbox,

463
00:28:18.370 --> 00:28:20.730
they're up there ready to authenticate.

464
00:28:20.730 --> 00:28:22.530
That's one more area.

465
00:28:22.530 --> 00:28:26.236
So, without getting crazy
in this particular piece,

466
00:28:26.236 --> 00:28:30.598
I just wanted to show you some of
the key troubleshooting areas.

467
00:28:30.598 --> 00:28:35.310
Is the service running, what did the last
one look like, were there any errors,

468
00:28:35.310 --> 00:28:39.282
we're a bunch of people removed or
a bunch of people added, right?

469
00:28:39.282 --> 00:28:42.858
Is the service running,
is the service account valid,

470
00:28:42.858 --> 00:28:44.844
is that locked out in Azure AD?

471
00:28:44.844 --> 00:28:47.162
Those are the basics for
troubleshooting and

472
00:28:47.162 --> 00:28:50.761
I think also look at the configuration
like we did initially because in

473
00:28:50.761 --> 00:28:54.550
the configuration you can validate
that you still have Exchange hybrid.

474
00:28:54.550 --> 00:28:57.800
The configuration hasn't changed
all those kinds of things.

475
00:28:57.800 --> 00:28:58.530
>> All right, Brian, well,

476
00:28:58.530 --> 00:29:02.950
that's a lot of information when we start
dealing with the idea of coexistence

477
00:29:02.950 --> 00:29:07.772
with Office 365 and Exchange Online
>> Remember that what you saw

478
00:29:07.772 --> 00:29:11.596
here in this episode is that, we saw
Brian help us with just dealing with

479
00:29:11.596 --> 00:29:16.268
the aspects of understanding what a Hybrid
configuration is going to be dealing with.

480
00:29:16.268 --> 00:29:21.188
Which, of course, is our on-premises
exchange as well as integrating in

481
00:29:21.188 --> 00:29:26.107
of course to some of our Office365s
Exchange Online and in that in the way

482
00:29:26.107 --> 00:29:30.969
he showed us is how we can begin by
using the Hybrid Configuration Wizard.

483
00:29:30.969 --> 00:29:33.980
He walked us through the settings
to get us setup there.

484
00:29:33.980 --> 00:29:37.070
And what we're looking for
at the end of that is that both sides were

485
00:29:37.070 --> 00:29:39.850
able to successfully get
the information that they need.

486
00:29:39.850 --> 00:29:42.640
And that they could actually
configure what they needed to for

487
00:29:42.640 --> 00:29:44.310
that exchange to go on.

488
00:29:44.310 --> 00:29:48.600
He also emphasized the importance of using
something like OAuth authentication.

489
00:29:48.600 --> 00:29:49.270
Because without it,

490
00:29:49.270 --> 00:29:53.530
some of the different services would
not run the way that they need to.

491
00:29:53.530 --> 00:29:58.050
And of course, firewall and
certificates always a big consideration.

492
00:29:58.050 --> 00:30:01.360
Remember those firewall rules,
they have to be open for

493
00:30:02.460 --> 00:30:07.450
port 443 and of course, for port 25, those
are things that we also wanna consider.

494
00:30:07.450 --> 00:30:11.040
And then, just troubleshooting
just the other things, right?

495
00:30:12.210 --> 00:30:15.690
Transport rules as well as
the client access and then lastly,

496
00:30:15.690 --> 00:30:20.480
even directory synchronization which is a
big part of just getting everything set up

497
00:30:20.480 --> 00:30:21.870
and making sure it's working.

498
00:30:21.870 --> 00:30:24.350
Directory synchronization Brian
is probably one of the areas I've

499
00:30:24.350 --> 00:30:28.100
had issues with in the past but glad
you asked, you helped me out there too.

500
00:30:28.100 --> 00:30:32.410
All right, Brian, as we get ready for
the exam, any last minute test, to seems

501
00:30:32.410 --> 00:30:37.380
like something I could possibly get set
up in the home lab and even run through.

502
00:30:37.380 --> 00:30:39.500
It doesn't seem like this
is a gigantic set up,

503
00:30:39.500 --> 00:30:41.340
is there anything else
that we can do here?

504
00:30:42.480 --> 00:30:44.060
>> Yeah, I think you nailed it, Ronnie.

505
00:30:44.060 --> 00:30:46.620
Which is, get your hands on it,
download the stuff,

506
00:30:46.620 --> 00:30:50.670
the synchronization tool is totally free,
you can actually synchronize

507
00:30:50.670 --> 00:30:54.670
without having to have any kind of
Azure Active Directory Premium.

508
00:30:54.670 --> 00:30:56.103
So, I would definitely walk through this.

509
00:30:56.103 --> 00:30:59.946
What you normally find is,
the prerequisites and some of the initial

510
00:30:59.946 --> 00:31:03.808
setup will really help you in
the troubleshooting scenarios later.

511
00:31:03.808 --> 00:31:06.120
>> All right, Brian.

512
00:31:06.120 --> 00:31:08.450
Thank you again for
helping us out with this.

513
00:31:08.450 --> 00:31:09.968
And thank you also for watching.

514
00:31:09.968 --> 00:31:12.548
This is a great place for

00:31:12.548 --> 00:31:15.322
For ITProTV, I've been your host,

00:31:16.504 --> 00:31:21.972
>> Stay tuned right here for
