>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie cover the Exchange Federation concepts.  They describe the connecting to the Azure AD Authentication System.  They also take a look at managing the sharing policies and organizational relationship.  Brian also reminds us that we must be concerned with certificates and firewall ports.  They close out the show with troubleshooting the Federation Trusts, Organizational Relationship and Cross-Forest Availability.
episodes.title: Exchange Federation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.243
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.243 --> 00:00:02.345
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.345 --> 00:00:05.154
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.154 --> 00:00:08.230
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.230 --> 00:00:11.770
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.770 --> 00:00:15.081
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.081 --> 00:00:19.837
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today
you're watching the show on planning,

8
00:00:19.837 --> 00:00:24.102
deploying, managing, and
troubleshooting exchange federation.

9
00:00:24.102 --> 00:00:27.099
Here to help us out with that
particular concept is gonna be Mr.

10
00:00:27.099 --> 00:00:29.430
Brian Svidergol, our Exchange expert.

11
00:00:29.430 --> 00:00:31.368
Brian, welcome back to the show, and

12
00:00:31.368 --> 00:00:34.407
help us out with this idea of
the Exchange Federation here.

13
00:00:34.407 --> 00:00:39.490
>> Sure, sure, so Exchange Federation,
think of it as a trust.

14
00:00:39.490 --> 00:00:42.453
And what you do is you take
your exchange organization and

15
00:00:42.453 --> 00:00:45.118
you trust it with another
exchange organization.

16
00:00:45.118 --> 00:00:50.308
One of the simplest ways to do that is
to start your federation with Microsoft.

17
00:00:50.308 --> 00:00:53.512
Microsoft Federation Services
is up in the cloud.

18
00:00:53.512 --> 00:00:58.100
They got a new name for it now, the Azure
Active Directory Authentication Services.

19
00:00:58.100 --> 00:01:02.131
But the idea here is that you
take your exchange orb and

20
00:01:02.131 --> 00:01:07.580
you have it trust Microsoft and
anybody else that does the same thing.

21
00:01:07.580 --> 00:01:10.510
If everyone trusts Microsoft,
you guys are now in a position

22
00:01:10.510 --> 00:01:14.960
to share stuff amongst each other
as though it was a direct trust.

23
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:17.274
So I've got a diagram,
let's walk through it for a second.

24
00:01:19.571 --> 00:01:23.423
So we've got company number
one over here on the left,

25
00:01:23.423 --> 00:01:26.540
company number two on the right.

26
00:01:26.540 --> 00:01:29.450
And each has their own
exchange organization, and

27
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:32.260
what they want to establish
is a relationship so

28
00:01:32.260 --> 00:01:38.430
they can share free busy information,
okay?

29
00:01:38.430 --> 00:01:44.110
And the establishment is
a self signed certificate, and

30
00:01:44.110 --> 00:01:47.580
a very quick click through
the exchange administrative center.

31
00:01:47.580 --> 00:01:50.460
I'm gonna actually show that
piece in our next topic.

32
00:01:50.460 --> 00:01:53.968
So after each company establishes
that federation trust.

33
00:01:53.968 --> 00:01:58.413
Now they can establish the policies
between the order like sharing

34
00:01:58.413 --> 00:02:00.200
the information.

35
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:03.587
So this is high level what it looks like,
one certificate each,

36
00:02:03.587 --> 00:02:06.985
a quick configuration in
the exchange administrative center.

37
00:02:06.985 --> 00:02:10.140
And then you're often ready
to go to the next piece,

38
00:02:10.140 --> 00:02:14.671
which is establishing sharing policies and
organisation relationship.

39
00:02:14.671 --> 00:02:18.165
>> Now what do we mean
by this idea of sharing?

40
00:02:18.165 --> 00:02:22.461
Now that we've got everything kind of
trusting, are we talking about the ability

41
00:02:22.461 --> 00:02:26.019
to limit what we share or
is this something else we're trying to do?

42
00:02:26.019 --> 00:02:31.340
>> Yeah, so we're talking about,
by default we don't share anything, right?

43
00:02:31.340 --> 00:02:35.117
So the only sharing that's taking
place is inside the organization.

44
00:02:35.117 --> 00:02:40.098
So when we talk about sharing, we're
talking about taking the information in

45
00:02:40.098 --> 00:02:43.882
our users mailboxes and
sharing it with external parties.

46
00:02:43.882 --> 00:02:49.896
And typically that's calendar or
contact information.

47
00:02:49.896 --> 00:02:53.400
So let's get started on
the sharing policies.

48
00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:57.100
I wanna show you visually what
we're sorta talking about.

49
00:02:58.620 --> 00:03:04.190
Bring the drop down to the computer,
mailbox server number one.

50
00:03:04.190 --> 00:03:06.548
And here we are in
the exchange admin center.

51
00:03:06.548 --> 00:03:10.790
We're gonna navigate over to organization
and then we're gonna go to sharing.

52
00:03:12.190 --> 00:03:15.630
And this is, and I'm gonna back
out of here just a little bit,

53
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:16.750
so we can do a zoom.

54
00:03:19.510 --> 00:03:20.570
This piece right here,

55
00:03:20.570 --> 00:03:23.385
that Federation Trust that I just
described on the other side.

56
00:03:23.385 --> 00:03:27.150
In a default environment
when we first come in here,

57
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:32.386
this would actually say Federate,
if I remember the button correctly.

58
00:03:32.386 --> 00:03:36.448
Because you have to click that,

>> All right, Brian, well thank you for
that tip as we get ready for that exam.

285
00:17:24.059 --> 00:17:26.218
And thank you also for watching.

286
00:17:26.218 --> 00:17:30.108
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

287
00:17:30.108 --> 00:17:31.478
>> And I'm Brian Svidergol.

288
00:17:31.478 --> 00:17:35.683
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft Exchange 2016 shows.

289
00:17:35.683 --> 00:17:42.892
[MUSIC]

290
00:17:42.892 --> 00:17:45.783
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie discuss some of the considerations when working in a environment with Exchange 2016 and earlier versions of Exchange.  They take a look at planning for names spaces for coexistence, show the planning of proxy redirection, mail flow, mailbox migrations, transport services and client access.
episodes.title: Coexistence with Earlier Exchange Versions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:02.382
I'm your host Don.

3
00:00:02.382 --> 00:00:04.623
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.623 --> 00:00:08.258
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.258 --> 00:00:11.798
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.798 --> 00:00:16.020
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.020 --> 00:00:20.940
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today you're
taking a look at planning, deploying,

8
00:00:20.940 --> 00:00:25.200
and troubleshooting
on-premises co-existence with

9
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:28.270
earlier versions of Microsoft Exchange.

10
00:00:28.270 --> 00:00:32.059
And here to help us out with that
entire topic is gonna be Mr.

11
00:00:32.059 --> 00:00:35.020
Brian our exchange expert.

12
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:38.210
Brian, welcome back to the show and
help us out.

13
00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:40.590
That was a mouthful to actually try and
do.

14
00:00:40.590 --> 00:00:42.470
And I don't I could repeat it again.

15
00:00:42.470 --> 00:00:44.515
I'm just happy that you
took that one Ronnie.

16
00:00:44.515 --> 00:00:47.570
[LAUGH] Glad to here
covering this topic today.

17
00:00:47.570 --> 00:00:51.050
Okay so the whole coexistence
with earlier versions

18
00:00:51.050 --> 00:00:54.330
we are gonna start today on name spaces.

19
00:00:55.495 --> 00:00:59.375
And namespace is, here's the deal
with namespace as an earlier version.

20
00:00:59.375 --> 00:01:04.025
If you go back a couple of versions,
especially all the way back to 2007,

21
00:01:04.025 --> 00:01:07.755
namespace planning for
coexistence was complex.

22
00:01:07.755 --> 00:01:12.830
It had a requirement that you had to
use a legacy domain name, and Often

23
00:01:12.830 --> 00:01:17.550
had to change out your certificates, your
SAN certificates with the legacy name and

24
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:20.200
all the new names and
then redeploy them to all the servers.

25
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:22.340
It made it a little bit challenging.

26
00:01:22.340 --> 00:01:26.380
Luckily for us, Exchange 2016
simplifies that whole process.

27
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:30.130
We no longer have that consideration for
the legacy host name.

28
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:33.740
But, there are a couple things that I
wanna walk through, I've got a diagram and

29
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:36.270
let's talk through it.

30
00:01:36.270 --> 00:01:41.390
So we're looking at a coexistence
environment, and we've got Exchange 2010.

31
00:01:41.390 --> 00:01:45.300
It doesn't matter if it's 2010 or
2013 and then here on the bottom,

32
00:01:45.300 --> 00:01:48.800
we have introduced Exchange 2016.

33
00:01:48.800 --> 00:01:52.130
So a couple of key points in
this coexistence environment.

34
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:53.530
When you have a mailbox on 2010,

35
00:01:53.530 --> 00:01:58.710
like the guy on the left here, you can
go to either server and get his email.

36
00:01:59.810 --> 00:02:03.400
When your mailbox is one
2016 after a mailbox move,

37
00:02:03.400 --> 00:02:08.340
you have to go straight to the mailbox
server that's running on 2016.

38
00:02:08.340 --> 00:02:12.160
So that's a little bit of information for
planning those name spaces.

39
00:02:12.160 --> 00:02:16.210
Because if your name spaces all
resolve to say, any exchange server in

40
00:02:16.210 --> 00:02:19.920
your environment, well that could pose
a problem in a scenario like this.

41
00:02:19.920 --> 00:02:23.520
Okay, with regard to
the rest of the name spaces.

42
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:24.720
Let's talk through those a little bit.

43
00:02:24.720 --> 00:02:27.060
I listed them out under number
three here on the bottom.

44
00:02:27.060 --> 00:02:29.010
We've got auto discover, Outlook Anywhere.

45
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:32.270
The whole list, we've kind of talked
through those through the days.

46
00:02:32.270 --> 00:02:34.970
I want to just talk from
the coexistence perspective,

47
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:37.780
the idea that it's a temporary state.

48
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:41.120
And that at some point,
you're going to want to take away all that

49
00:02:41.120 --> 00:02:44.030
old legacy exchange equipment and
bring in 2016.

50
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:47.230
And it's part of that,
that name space planning,

51
00:02:47.230 --> 00:02:52.920
is which name spaces do you cut over first
And what the whole over process look like?

52
00:02:52.920 --> 00:02:57.330
I would like to point out one thing here,
auto discover is usually the first name

53
00:02:57.330 --> 00:03:02.310
space that you bring over to exchange 2016
and that is usually one of the safest.

54
00:03:02.310 --> 00:03:05.800
After that you usually bring the rest of
them in bulk it may be cut over weekend or

55
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:07.210
something similar.

56
00:03:07.210 --> 00:03:12.110
So high level namespace planning be
thinking in the order you bring them over.

57
00:03:12.110 --> 00:03:15.190
Be thinking about your certificates so
that you can have

58
00:03:15.190 --> 00:03:20.310
all your Exchange environment, the old and
the new, all on the same certificate.

59
00:03:20.310 --> 00:03:23.110
>> Now, Brian, with actually trying
to implement something like this

60
00:03:23.110 --> 00:03:27.210
with a previous version, and
now of course Exchange 2016.

61
00:03:27.210 --> 00:03:31.070
We also may need to consider,
of course, then planning and

62
00:03:31.070 --> 00:03:34.330
configuring for proxy redirection as well.

63
00:03:34.330 --> 00:03:38.250
And it's an element that we really
need to make sure that we cover.

64
00:03:38.250 --> 00:03:40.320
So Brian what is it that
we need to understand here?

65
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:45.510
>> So this topic we've covered
a little bit in the past.

66
00:03:45.510 --> 00:03:48.900
And this one, what this exam has,

67
00:03:48.900 --> 00:03:52.840
it takes some of these same topics and
shoves them in to different categories.

68
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:56.900
Some for hybrid, some for coexistence,
and some just for implementing and

69
00:03:56.900 --> 00:03:59.160
planning your Exchange 2016 environment,
right.

70
00:03:59.160 --> 00:04:03.190
So, the good news is we can take some
of the same concepts from earlier and

71
00:04:03.190 --> 00:04:04.530
apply them in this case.

72
00:04:04.530 --> 00:04:07.638
I have a new diagram, I'm going to walk
through the proxy and redirect, right now.

73
00:04:11.435 --> 00:04:14.060
Okay, so here is our diagram.

74
00:04:14.060 --> 00:04:16.540
This is an all new proxy redirect diagram.

75
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:18.660
You guys probably remember that.

76
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:24.400
We have our user here, he comes in
initially to any mailbox server,

77
00:04:24.400 --> 00:04:29.450
and then he is proxy back
to whatever his mailbox is

78
00:04:29.450 --> 00:04:31.870
As long as the sites
are not internet facing.

79
00:04:32.960 --> 00:04:34.790
If he has an internet facing site,

80
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:39.240
then he can be redirected
all the way to that server.

81
00:04:39.240 --> 00:04:42.440
All this proxy redirect
stuff happens seamlessly.

82
00:04:44.060 --> 00:04:49.930
So For coexistence,
there's not a whole lot changing here.

83
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:57.140
I did cover one thing earlier,
which is that 2016 can proxy for

84
00:04:57.140 --> 00:05:01.019
2010 or 2016 or 2013.

85
00:05:01.019 --> 00:05:05.876
But if you go back to 2010, most of
the time what you're gonna find is that

86
00:05:05.876 --> 00:05:09.910
the older versions can't proxy for
the newer versions.

87
00:05:09.910 --> 00:05:11.140
And so you have to account for

88
00:05:11.140 --> 00:05:16.190
that when you're directing people through
the environment to get their email.

89
00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:18.840
>> Another issue that we
might not have considered,

90
00:05:18.840 --> 00:05:24.470
especially as we're running this idea of
a coexistence a type of infrastructure

91
00:05:24.470 --> 00:05:29.610
here is also doing the firewall
types of planning as well.

92
00:05:29.610 --> 00:05:34.390
So in earlier versions Brian, we have to
worry about different follow ports or

93
00:05:34.390 --> 00:05:38.320
we actually need to do when we have
this idea of the older version and

94
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:42.290
the newer versions in this
special considerations there.

95
00:05:42.290 --> 00:05:46.930
The only special consideration are if
that more serves to deal with.

96
00:05:46.930 --> 00:05:52.050
And when you first bring 2016 in, all your
firewall rules are probably setup just for

97
00:05:52.050 --> 00:05:53.540
your legacy environment.

98
00:05:53.540 --> 00:05:58.740
So you need to alter, you've got all the
different ports of 25, the AD, the 443 you

99
00:05:58.740 --> 00:06:02.530
need to open those up for the new servers
and make sure all of it is included.

100
00:06:02.530 --> 00:06:05.190
Once you've done your migration or
cut over,

101
00:06:05.190 --> 00:06:08.960
you take out all the old equipment out
of the firewall rules and you're good.

102
00:06:08.960 --> 00:06:11.770
Let's look at the firewall
chart in a diagram and

103
00:06:11.770 --> 00:06:12.970
walk through some of those ports.

104
00:06:14.870 --> 00:06:20.250
Okay, so here we have what we
call the core services and

105
00:06:20.250 --> 00:06:22.390
they are all listed here on the left.

106
00:06:22.390 --> 00:06:27.179
And then we have the protocol, TCP or UDP,
and then we list out the port numbers.

107
00:06:28.750 --> 00:06:29.850
Some of you guys obviously,

108
00:06:29.850 --> 00:06:32.380
most of you guys are gonna know
the standard ports 80, 443, 25.

109
00:06:32.380 --> 00:06:40.018
But we're still getting into POP3
secure point 995 and IMAP secure 993.

110
00:06:40.018 --> 00:06:42.990
That might get a little murky for
some people,

111
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:44.509
not everyone memorizes those things.

112
00:06:45.830 --> 00:06:50.905
Another one down here is authenticated
SMTP from the clients on 587.

113
00:06:50.905 --> 00:06:55.608
So, not that you need to remember
all these or memorize them, but

114
00:06:55.608 --> 00:07:00.140
there is a chance that you could
see some ports on the exam.

115
00:07:00.140 --> 00:07:02.130
So having a little table like this,

116
00:07:02.130 --> 00:07:06.030
looking at it before you walk
into the exam, not a bad idea.

117
00:07:06.030 --> 00:07:12.310
One thing on the DNS, it's the only
one that has both TCP and UDP.

118
00:07:12.310 --> 00:07:13.660
So be aware of that,

119
00:07:13.660 --> 00:07:16.340
that's another thing on the firewall
side that's you've gotta account for.

120
00:07:17.900 --> 00:07:21.110
>> The other thing that we also want to
consider of course is having to deal with

121
00:07:21.110 --> 00:07:23.610
the idea of mailflow requirements.

122
00:07:23.610 --> 00:07:28.140
So with Exchange 2016, we've already
gone through that in earlier episodes.

123
00:07:28.140 --> 00:07:30.520
But now that you're talking
about earlier versions, and

124
00:07:30.520 --> 00:07:33.790
of course the current version of Exchange.

125
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:38.460
We need to be able to understand
how this affects our mail flow and

126
00:07:38.460 --> 00:07:39.990
what we need to configure for.

127
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:42.570
So, Brian, help us out here.

128
00:07:42.570 --> 00:07:46.646
>> So, mail flow requirements
>> I think the easiest way is to think

129
00:07:46.646 --> 00:07:50.358
them through is let's go to the virtual
white board and draw out and

130
00:07:50.358 --> 00:07:52.760
talk through some of these requirements.

131
00:07:55.118 --> 00:07:59.044
All right, so the white board is up and

132
00:07:59.044 --> 00:08:02.978
I first want to talk about MX records.

133
00:08:02.978 --> 00:08:05.462
So, earlier, we've kind of drawn this out.

134
00:08:05.462 --> 00:08:07.350
We've got an MX record here.

135
00:08:07.350 --> 00:08:11.929
10 going to your old exchange, say 2013.

136
00:08:11.929 --> 00:08:18.178
So, when we think about mail flow, and
we've brought 2016 into the environment.

137
00:08:18.178 --> 00:08:21.021
One of the first things we've got
to think about is the MX record.

138
00:08:21.021 --> 00:08:22.830
So that's step one.

139
00:08:24.370 --> 00:08:26.750
I'm gonna actually leave that up.

140
00:08:26.750 --> 00:08:29.720
We also have connectors.

141
00:08:29.720 --> 00:08:33.290
So send connectors, say to the internet,

142
00:08:33.290 --> 00:08:38.030
normally list out the servers
that are authorised to send.

143
00:08:38.030 --> 00:08:39.660
Right?
So you're gonna have your old servers

144
00:08:39.660 --> 00:08:42.630
listed out as authorized to
send email out to the internet.

145
00:08:42.630 --> 00:08:47.403
When you bring your new servers in over
here on 2016, you're going to need to

146
00:08:47.403 --> 00:08:52.123
update your connectors, so that they
authorize your new servers to also send.

147
00:08:52.123 --> 00:08:58.835
And that's going to be whether
you're sending or receiving, okay?

148
00:08:58.835 --> 00:09:00.544
I'm going to erase this stuff and
keep going.

149
00:09:03.005 --> 00:09:08.510
So another thing I wanna
talk about is SMTP relay.

150
00:09:08.510 --> 00:09:12.930
So, many organizations
specify one Exchange server

151
00:09:12.930 --> 00:09:17.060
in all the other servers
use it to send emails.

152
00:09:17.060 --> 00:09:20.300
Well now you brought 2016 in over here.

153
00:09:20.300 --> 00:09:22.730
And you've got a couple of
updates to make here right.

154
00:09:22.730 --> 00:09:28.070
You probably have to update a DNS record,
maybe it's SMTP.yourdomain.com or

155
00:09:28.070 --> 00:09:31.670
something like that and
you want that DNS to point down here.

156
00:09:31.670 --> 00:09:35.800
But you're also going to have to
configure the IP address space for

157
00:09:35.800 --> 00:09:37.250
authorized senders.

158
00:09:37.250 --> 00:09:39.210
So let's list that out.

159
00:09:39.210 --> 00:09:45.660
IP addresses, and if you don't have
this DNS, you're going to have to

160
00:09:45.660 --> 00:09:51.190
update all these clients with the IP
address of the new SMTP server.

161
00:09:51.190 --> 00:09:53.060
The one running on 2016.

162
00:09:53.060 --> 00:09:57.694
So let me erase this and
see if we have any additional stuff here.

163
00:10:00.666 --> 00:10:04.737
I think that's probably a good coverage
for mailflow, it's a lot of stuff to take

164
00:10:04.737 --> 00:10:08.960
in and hopefully the whiteboard
helps visualize some of that stuff.

165
00:10:08.960 --> 00:10:12.230
>> Now, as we start to integrate
everything together as far

166
00:10:12.230 --> 00:10:14.130
as this coexistence goes.

167
00:10:14.130 --> 00:10:18.260
One of the things that we do want to
also do is of course is to move earlier

168
00:10:18.260 --> 00:10:23.460
mailboxes to the current edition
of Microsoft Exchange as well.

169
00:10:23.460 --> 00:10:27.000
So what do we need to plan for
in terms of mailbox move or migration.

170
00:10:28.180 --> 00:10:31.900
>> So for migration, there is
quite a lot of planning aspect and

171
00:10:31.900 --> 00:10:33.480
things to think about, right?

172
00:10:33.480 --> 00:10:37.680
So one, you want to figure out how
you are going to do you mailbox.

173
00:10:37.680 --> 00:10:39.340
Are you gonna move them in batches?

174
00:10:39.340 --> 00:10:40.310
Are you gonna move them all at once?

175
00:10:40.310 --> 00:10:42.680
You're gonna have a cut over weekend.

176
00:10:42.680 --> 00:10:46.710
Typically, smaller environments, couple
hundred mailboxes, maybe two, three,

177
00:10:46.710 --> 00:10:49.520
four hundred mailboxes,
you can do a cut over weekend.

178
00:10:49.520 --> 00:10:51.260
Friday night, everybody goes home.

179
00:10:51.260 --> 00:10:53.180
Monday morning, they come back in.

180
00:10:53.180 --> 00:10:54.160
They're up on 2016.

181
00:10:54.160 --> 00:10:55.810
Nobody knows what happened.

182
00:10:55.810 --> 00:10:57.875
In bigger organizations though,
that's not always gonna work.

183
00:10:57.875 --> 00:11:02.530
You got 10, 20,000 mailboxes,
you're gonna move them in batches.

184
00:11:02.530 --> 00:11:06.500
And planning for batches is something that
requires a little bit of consideration.

185
00:11:06.500 --> 00:11:09.960
One, how do you move all
the mailboxes to 2016 and have

186
00:11:11.450 --> 00:11:17.440
all your database sizes match up and
align and minimize downtime for the users.

187
00:11:17.440 --> 00:11:22.580
Manage all of the quotas and all of
the other things that users are used to.

188
00:11:22.580 --> 00:11:24.040
That's gonna take some time.

189
00:11:24.040 --> 00:11:27.210
So I wanna walk through a couple things,
some commands.

190
00:11:27.210 --> 00:11:33.110
Let's drop down to the computer and
take a look at mailbox server number one.

191
00:11:33.110 --> 00:11:38.170
So one of the planning components
is getting your mailboxes and

192
00:11:38.170 --> 00:11:40.680
figuring out on DB1 here.

193
00:11:40.680 --> 00:11:43.450
Let's go to -Database DB1.

194
00:11:43.450 --> 00:11:47.870
And you wanna figure out how big they are,
how many you have.

195
00:11:47.870 --> 00:11:50.680
So we're gonna use
a Get-MailboxStatistics.

196
00:11:50.680 --> 00:11:56.710
There it is and
then I'm gonna format a table and

197
00:11:56.710 --> 00:12:01.080
say display name total item size.

198
00:12:02.430 --> 00:12:06.050
And this is one database maybe this
is the first database I wanna move,

199
00:12:06.050 --> 00:12:10.740
maybe this data base is on is the last
database on one of my mailbox servers.

200
00:12:10.740 --> 00:12:14.550
So I wanna find out who's on it, figure
out how much data I'm working with and

201
00:12:14.550 --> 00:12:16.080
then plan out those moves.

202
00:12:16.080 --> 00:12:21.180
So this command gives me all
the mailboxes and their total item size.

203
00:12:21.180 --> 00:12:23.820
Notice that yellow lettering
that warning text,

204
00:12:23.820 --> 00:12:28.098
we have a few mailboxes on
the database that never logged in.

205
00:12:28.098 --> 00:12:31.140
Typically you won't see that often
in a production environment,

206
00:12:31.140 --> 00:12:33.790
this being a lab environment we just
have a bunch of tests stuff out there.

207
00:12:35.440 --> 00:12:37.430
So, we've got a few with some size.

208
00:12:37.430 --> 00:12:41.040
We're looking at a couple megs, some KB,
right, at the lab environment but

209
00:12:41.040 --> 00:12:43.170
normally you're working with gigabits.

210
00:12:43.170 --> 00:12:47.440
And what you're trying to identify is how
much total data is there, how long is it

211
00:12:47.440 --> 00:12:53.120
going to take to copy across and do I have
enough room on the destination server.

212
00:12:53.120 --> 00:12:56.200
Can I move all this stuff on
database one on the old server?

213
00:12:56.200 --> 00:12:58.420
To a single database on the new server?

214
00:12:58.420 --> 00:13:02.460
Or am I gonna have to actually break
these up with some kind of spreadsheet?

215
00:13:03.900 --> 00:13:05.400
Let me move on a little bit here.

216
00:13:06.530 --> 00:13:11.660
So next, let's say I've identified,
that my God, a few mailboxes.

217
00:13:11.660 --> 00:13:13.300
There's not that much data.

218
00:13:13.300 --> 00:13:15.430
Let's look at how you
can move these things.

219
00:13:15.430 --> 00:13:19.020
So we're gonna, get mailbox database DB1,

220
00:13:19.020 --> 00:13:23.749
we are gonna specify a New-MoveRequest.

221
00:13:23.749 --> 00:13:31.232
We are gonna specify a TargetDatabase,
we are gonna put, everybody on DB10.

222
00:13:31.232 --> 00:13:34.496
We are gonna give this Batch-Move a name,

223
00:13:34.496 --> 00:13:39.766
I normally like to say which database
the source is of DB1 to DB10.

224
00:13:39.766 --> 00:13:43.796
That way if I look at it later, I can at
least identified where things were coming

225
00:13:43.796 --> 00:13:45.800
from and where they are supposed to go.

226
00:13:45.800 --> 00:13:49.960
I'm going to set a BadItemLimit, so

227
00:13:49.960 --> 00:13:55.260
when you move a mailbox you might
come across bad items, corrupt items.

228
00:13:55.260 --> 00:13:58.860
You can either have the mailbox
move completely stopped or

229
00:13:58.860 --> 00:14:01.960
you can accept a few bad items and
keep moving.

230
00:14:01.960 --> 00:14:06.340
In general what I have found you
need to accept some bad items.

231
00:14:06.340 --> 00:14:10.761
50 is a pretty good number that balances
data loss and functionality and

232
00:14:10.761 --> 00:14:13.337
actually getting this process complete.

233
00:14:13.337 --> 00:14:18.166
And then we're gonna say CompleteAfter and

234
00:14:18.166 --> 00:14:24.454
we're gonna say 03/18/2017 10:00AM.

235
00:14:24.454 --> 00:14:28.860
And this particular window aligned
with my change request that I put in

236
00:14:28.860 --> 00:14:29.730
nd has been approved.

237
00:14:29.730 --> 00:14:31.120
So that's good.

238
00:14:32.760 --> 00:14:34.640
We're going to go ahead and kick that off.

239
00:14:34.640 --> 00:14:38.600
You can see that we get information
about when an item can't be read,

240
00:14:38.600 --> 00:14:40.600
let me scroll back up to that.

241
00:14:40.600 --> 00:14:42.460
When an item can't be
read from the source,

242
00:14:42.460 --> 00:14:45.350
it can't be written to the destination,
it's considered corrupted.

243
00:14:45.350 --> 00:14:47.520
That's where that bad item limit comes in.

244
00:14:47.520 --> 00:14:50.659
So you can see if it's out
a few of these mailboxes,

245
00:14:50.659 --> 00:14:53.293
some of these have never been logged into.

246
00:14:55.615 --> 00:14:59.230
And we have one mailbox that all
ready has a completed move request.

247
00:14:59.230 --> 00:15:00.770
I can show you that in
a couple more minutes.

248
00:15:02.310 --> 00:15:03.250
Completed move request.

249
00:15:03.250 --> 00:15:06.500
I've moved a few mailboxes in between,
it didn't clear them out.

250
00:15:06.500 --> 00:15:08.140
The rest of these are waiting for
the pickup job,

251
00:15:08.140 --> 00:15:10.200
which is that date that we specified.

252
00:15:10.200 --> 00:15:11.939
So, there you have.

253
00:15:13.050 --> 00:15:16.270
We'll call it one small
batch of moving mailboxes.

254
00:15:16.270 --> 00:15:19.490
And now,
what I wanna show you is the third part.

255
00:15:19.490 --> 00:15:23.500
So now we've said DB1
is on the old server.

256
00:15:23.500 --> 00:15:24.720
We wanna eliminate that.

257
00:15:24.720 --> 00:15:26.696
We're gonna move everything to DB10, but

258
00:15:26.696 --> 00:15:29.440
I need one more command to
kind of complete the process.

259
00:15:29.440 --> 00:15:34.260
Set mailbox database DB1 and then we're

260
00:15:34.260 --> 00:15:39.635
gonna use the IsExcluded
from provisioning.

261
00:15:39.635 --> 00:15:40.970
There it is.

262
00:15:40.970 --> 00:15:43.340
And we're gonna set that to true.

263
00:15:43.340 --> 00:15:45.370
So, what that does.

264
00:15:45.370 --> 00:15:49.710
You guys remember how we have
been creating new mailboxes,

265
00:15:49.710 --> 00:15:53.720
not specifying a database, and
Exchange sort of chooses it for us?

266
00:15:53.720 --> 00:15:56.671
This makes sure Exchange
doesn't choose DB1 anymore.

267
00:15:56.671 --> 00:15:59.519
Because we're moving everybody
off DB1 to a new database and

268
00:15:59.519 --> 00:16:03.185
we want to get rid of the server that
DB1's on, I don't want any more mailboxes

269
00:16:03.185 --> 00:16:07.066
being automatically placed there,
cuz I'm just gonna have to move them.

270
00:16:07.066 --> 00:16:11.710
So that gives you a high level look
at the process of planning and

271
00:16:11.710 --> 00:16:13.390
then walking through at least the basics.

272
00:16:14.590 --> 00:16:16.280
>> Now the other consideration, of course,

273
00:16:16.280 --> 00:16:19.130
just like in any Exchange
server that we have to consider

274
00:16:19.130 --> 00:16:23.120
is gonna be troubleshooting
the transport services itself.

275
00:16:23.120 --> 00:16:27.690
So, Brian, in the coexistence situation,
are there any thing, is there anything

276
00:16:27.690 --> 00:16:31.580
different that we need to do, even though
we already looked at this in 2016?

277
00:16:31.580 --> 00:16:34.160
>> Not really, actually.

278
00:16:34.160 --> 00:16:37.880
Obviously, like we talked earlier,
the same topic in a hybrid,

279
00:16:37.880 --> 00:16:40.440
right, you need to look
often in two places.

280
00:16:40.440 --> 00:16:44.850
Troubleshooting becomes a little more
complex, but I am gonna show you some of

281
00:16:44.850 --> 00:16:48.100
the logging components that will
help during this troubleshooting.

282
00:16:48.100 --> 00:16:53.496
So let's go back to mailbox
server number one, and

283
00:16:53.496 --> 00:17:01.663
we are gonna start by clearing that
Get-ReceiveConnector -Server MBX1.

284
00:17:01.663 --> 00:17:09.690
We're gonna
Select Name,ProtocolLoggingLevel.

285
00:17:09.690 --> 00:17:12.920
So this shows all of our
received connectors on MBX1 and

286
00:17:12.920 --> 00:17:15.280
what their logging level is.

287
00:17:15.280 --> 00:17:18.040
We have two set to Verbose,
three that are set to None.

288
00:17:18.040 --> 00:17:22.910
In a troubleshooting scenario, we normally
like to turn the logging up all the way.

289
00:17:22.910 --> 00:17:28.810
Not necessarily across the board, but
once you've identified maybe the server or

290
00:17:28.810 --> 00:17:30.930
the connector that's involved,
you can set the logging up.

291
00:17:30.930 --> 00:17:35.190
If you're totally at a lost,
sometimes you can turn it all up and

292
00:17:35.190 --> 00:17:36.880
then flip it back down once you're done.

293
00:17:36.880 --> 00:17:39.110
So let's take a look here.

294
00:17:39.110 --> 00:17:42.144
We're gonna do a set-ReceiveConnector.

295
00:17:43.720 --> 00:17:47.925
And we are going to specify

296
00:17:47.925 --> 00:17:54.510
"MBX1\Client Frontend MBX1" and then we're

297
00:17:56.570 --> 00:18:01.500
going to say
-ProtocolLoggingLevel Verbous.

298
00:18:03.200 --> 00:18:08.080
Now let's rerun the earlier command
just to make sure that it worked.

299
00:18:08.080 --> 00:18:11.690
And now what you're seeing is we have
flipped up one of the loging levels to

300
00:18:11.690 --> 00:18:12.780
Verbose.

301
00:18:12.780 --> 00:18:14.440
We could've also flipped them all on.

302
00:18:14.440 --> 00:18:15.980
But it just kinda shows you how quick and

303
00:18:15.980 --> 00:18:19.530
easy it is to flip those
logging levels up.

304
00:18:19.530 --> 00:18:20.155
Let's keep moving.

305
00:18:25.178 --> 00:18:27.644
So I wanna go back to message tracking,

306
00:18:27.644 --> 00:18:32.803
because this is an important one to help
you figure out what servers are involved,

307
00:18:32.803 --> 00:18:37.110
what the timestamps are, and
maybe which logs to look at.

308
00:18:37.110 --> 00:18:40.684
So we're gonna go back to Jack.Jackson.

309
00:18:43.782 --> 00:18:47.522
.net, say Start,

310
00:18:47.522 --> 00:18:52.369
we're gonna get- Date.

311
00:18:54.601 --> 00:18:56.481
A lot of tab completion with that.

312
00:18:56.481 --> 00:19:03.893
There we go, .Addhours, the last 96 hours.

313
00:19:03.893 --> 00:19:05.482
And you know what I wanna do?

314
00:19:05.482 --> 00:19:07.225
I'm gonna run this and then,

315
00:19:07.225 --> 00:19:11.920
I'm gonna do one more after this cuz this
gonna bring back a ton of information.

316
00:19:11.920 --> 00:19:13.810
And we've seen that before.

317
00:19:13.810 --> 00:19:19.850
So let me do an invoke-history, number 23,
and break it down a little bit better,

318
00:19:19.850 --> 00:19:23.050
just an earlier command I popped
in there to save us some typing.

319
00:19:23.050 --> 00:19:27.940
So MessageTracking, I'm just bringing
back the sender, the message subject,

320
00:19:27.940 --> 00:19:32.110
but this one of those other log files,
I know we covered a bit of it earlier,

321
00:19:32.110 --> 00:19:36.640
that helps you kinda troubleshoot and
it's whether it's coexistence,

322
00:19:36.640 --> 00:19:40.830
hybrid or just independent Exchange 2016.

323
00:19:40.830 --> 00:19:46.410
>> All right Brian, since we also covered
the idea of client access earlier as well,

324
00:19:46.410 --> 00:19:49.340
what about any difference
in troubleshooting client

325
00:19:49.340 --> 00:19:51.820
access in this coexistent
environment as well?

326
00:19:53.070 --> 00:19:56.960
>> So the main thing is, when we think
about coexistence, we're thinking about

327
00:19:56.960 --> 00:19:59.740
different servers, we're thinking
about different name spaces,

328
00:19:59.740 --> 00:20:02.052
and a lot of changes to name spaces.

329
00:20:02.052 --> 00:20:05.320
Auto discover, being the first one
that we're going to move over.

330
00:20:05.320 --> 00:20:08.510
One of the best ways to troubleshoot
this is go to the client, go to Outlook,

331
00:20:08.510 --> 00:20:12.140
and take a look at the test
email auto-configuration.

332
00:20:12.140 --> 00:20:15.100
We did look at it one time
before a couple of days back,

333
00:20:15.100 --> 00:20:17.510
different scenario, same test.

334
00:20:17.510 --> 00:20:20.541
Let's go back to that now on client one.

335
00:20:25.970 --> 00:20:29.355
Here we are on client one,
we've got Outlook running.

336
00:20:34.031 --> 00:20:37.660
And we're gonna test
Email AutoConfiguration.

337
00:20:37.660 --> 00:20:39.760
We might need to zoom in for this.

338
00:20:39.760 --> 00:20:41.870
I'm gonna get that kinda centered up here.

339
00:20:44.862 --> 00:20:48.890
So we are logged on as Tom.Zeller@hugelab.

340
00:20:48.890 --> 00:20:52.551
We're gonna uncheck these
two options right here,

341
00:20:52.551 --> 00:20:58.052
the whole guess smart stuff, and as soon
as we do that we're gonna click Test.

342
00:21:01.628 --> 00:21:05.227
And I'm gonna go back full screen,
and at least to see,

343
00:21:05.227 --> 00:21:08.220
okay, let's go back to the zoom in here.

344
00:21:08.220 --> 00:21:10.530
So in a coexistence scenario,

345
00:21:10.530 --> 00:21:14.990
the very first thing we wanna figure out,
are all of these URLs.

346
00:21:14.990 --> 00:21:17.588
You can see them listed down here,

347
00:21:17.588 --> 00:21:23.150
because in a coexistence scenario
there are complication with the URLs.

348
00:21:23.150 --> 00:21:29.220
Especially if we've started the process
of introducing 2016 in for auto discover.

349
00:21:29.220 --> 00:21:31.840
Auto discover being the one that,
if that's broken,

350
00:21:31.840 --> 00:21:35.320
clients are gonna have trouble finding
their mailbox and getting connected.

351
00:21:35.320 --> 00:21:37.680
So, this particular test is key.

352
00:21:37.680 --> 00:21:41.292
I know we've seen it before, but
I wanted to reiterate it's importance.

353
00:21:41.292 --> 00:21:43.740
>> All right Brian,

354
00:21:43.740 --> 00:21:48.170
well that's a lot of things to consider,
especially if we are running in this

355
00:21:48.170 --> 00:21:52.892
coexistence environment with earlier
editions of Exchanges out there.

356
00:21:52.892 --> 00:21:57.690
Remember that in this episode we did
talk a little bit about this idea

357
00:21:57.690 --> 00:22:02.510
of making sure that we take care of
the name spaces in coexistence, so

358
00:22:02.510 --> 00:22:05.160
we have to make sure that
everything is actually right there.

359
00:22:05.160 --> 00:22:07.420
Also Brian took us through planning for,

360
00:22:07.420 --> 00:22:11.930
of course, a proxy redirection
when we needed to, as well as

361
00:22:11.930 --> 00:22:17.020
firewall types of information for
that coexistence, and even mail flow.

362
00:22:17.020 --> 00:22:21.850
And lastly, we took a look,
of course, about the mailbox

363
00:22:21.850 --> 00:22:25.260
migrations themselves,
along with the transport and

364
00:22:25.260 --> 00:22:29.560
the client access considerations that
are also there in trouble-shooting

365
00:22:29.560 --> 00:22:34.860
when we actually have two different
versions of Microsoft Exchange running.

366
00:22:34.860 --> 00:22:39.210
Brian, this sounds a little bit more
challenging in terms of getting

367
00:22:39.210 --> 00:22:42.350
a lab set up to make sure
that we practice this.

368
00:22:42.350 --> 00:22:46.860
Any hints that you can give
us as we get ready for

369
00:22:46.860 --> 00:22:50.550
the exam, because it does sound a little
bit more challenging now that you're

370
00:22:50.550 --> 00:22:53.930
adding in another version of
Microsoft Exchange in there?

371
00:22:54.970 --> 00:23:00.020
>> Yeah,
occasionally Microsoft offers an online

372
00:23:00.020 --> 00:23:05.140
virtual lab where there is a coexistence
scenario already built out for

373
00:23:05.140 --> 00:23:09.960
you and kind of shows you the process of
going through the upgrade, the migration.

374
00:23:09.960 --> 00:23:12.420
Those aren't always available,
but when they are,

375
00:23:12.420 --> 00:23:15.770
they're definitely worth checking out
because, again, setting this all up from

376
00:23:15.770 --> 00:23:20.840
the ground up just to cover a couple

377
00:23:21.860 --> 00:23:25.620
>> All right Brian, well thank you again
for helping us out in this particular

378
00:23:25.620 --> 00:23:28.290
situation when we do

379
00:23:28.290 --> 00:23:33.680
And thank you also for watching us as we
continue on through Microsoft Exchange.

380
00:23:33.680 --> 00:23:37.050
But there are more shows to come,

00:23:37.050 --> 00:23:41.320
And so signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

00:23:41.320 --> 00:23:42.560
>> And I'm Brian Svidergol.

00:23:42.560 --> 00:23:46.288

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Ronnie take a look at migrating from earlier versions of Exchange to Exchange 2016.  They describe and distinguished different migration paths depending on the scenario.  Also, the guys take a look at migrating mailboxes, migrating to modern public folders.  Brian also helps us to consider planning for features found in earlier versions of Exchange that are de-emphasized or discontinued in Exchange 2016.  With his experience, Brian brings up considerations for transitioning and decommissioning servers before final steps of getting rid of earlier Exchange servers and takes a look at troubleshooting the Mailbox Replication Services.
episodes.title: Migrate from Earlier Exchange Versions

topics.title: Implement and manage coexistence, hybrid scenarios, migration, and federation
